Got gifted this game recently, finally finished it. I played it a few times as a kid, have fond memories, but the puzzles were often too much back then. Really good game to get your gears spinning, puzzles can be quite challenging at times. I'm also in love with the visual style. The hand-drawn nature of the game's assets really breathes life into the world you're put in.

One preety ugly issue tho, all through the game, I was getting regular lag/stutter issues. The game would just lag for a couple seconds, slowing down the game with it, based on some things I've seen (eg, in hint book minigame, during the lag, I was able to shoot many more bullets in the same time) It seems like it's the game's ticks lagging behind, not just the graphics frames (they could be tied anyway). My computer is a high-end as of 2020, most new AAA releases have no issues running smoothly, yet this 20 year old 2D game has issues. This has been a major annoyance throughout. Still, looking it up, not many people reported this, so chances are you won't have this issue.

149767725.review:
Despite having called myself a fan of adventure games since I played Myst, The Journeyman Project TURBO! and Riven as a kid in the mid-1990s, there are plenty of legendary adventure games that I haven't played.  Machinarium is one of those and I've finally played it.

It started a year and a half ago when I noticed Samorost in my Steam library, also created by Amanita Design.  I played the trilogy of Samorost games and came to appreciate this developer's style of adventure game.  It's also when I remembered Machinarium.

https://steamcommunity.com/id/Eincrou/recommended/421120

Machinarium is no less whimsical and quirky than Samorost... and no less challenging.  There were several times I got legitimately stuck.  Interactions can be obscure and there are some small objects that are tough to notice.  I consulted the in-game guidebook a few times, which is cryptic enough to still require some thought.

There are some arcade-style games that were a nice change of pace, but I think some went on for too long.  The one to kill 40 enemies in a maze was excessive.

I didn't actually make any moves to buy and play Machinarium until I was out this past summer and played the demo for an upcoming adventure game called Boxville on PS5, which had been previously released on PC.  Its style reminded me again of Machinarium.

https://store.steampowered.com/app/1750710/Boxville/

When I was able to return home, Machinarium was the first new PC game I bought.  Maybe I'll get Boxville sometime, too.  Though not on PS5... playing point & click with a gamepad sucks.

This review has barely been about Machinarium, but come on.  The game has been out for 14 years.  There are already a billion reviews describing it.  If you're like I was, an adventure game fan whom has never played it, then get on it.

148719812.review:
I don't know if its just me but finally being able to play Machinarium was nostalgic. I remember when I was younger and this game had only been out for a few years, and my class had begun to take an interest in playing it. I can recall my friends playing and talking about how great it was; all while I, the most tech illiterate and internet sheltered in the class (At least what I thought during the time) was unable to play it due to my parents not thinking that cheap mobile games such as this would be of any use to me. Something wherein I guess they where right, this game wouldn't have, and didn't change me with its fun story, amazing art, or fantastical score. Yet, it did work to do something in me by merely existing. For the fact that my understanding of what made a game something I wanted to play was fundamentally challenged. I was upset that I wouldn't play it in the time that it was popular amongst my friend group. But as I thought more, and grew up I remembered this story and it made me think, even right now as I write this I question why I play, but more importantly, feel driven to buy the games I do. When I bought this game earlier this month I did so for two reasons. One, it was on sale and cheap, a whole other factor within itself; and second because of the memories of never being able to play it before and wanting to know what made it "Great" in other peoples eyes. Which yeah, now having played it I can see why it was so good, but I cant help but think that if it were not for it my parents not buying it, or for the class being intrigued by it, my chance of being here right now would have been significantly decreased. I might have found it on my own, and the art might have made me interested enough to buy, and I would have had probably the same amount of enjoy-ability playing it. But I don't know this review is becoming a mess, and I don't even know what I am trying to say, if anything at all. I just want to know why we buy things. We like knowing or receiving positive reviews of games before we okay them, but why? Why should a game be considered any less then just because some people hated it, and why must we bully people for liking things other might not. This is gaming, there are soooooo many games out there in the vast web of what the internet has allowed humanity to achieve. Do I buy games because they are popular? Do I buy games because people think they are good? Because someone wrote a super long review of something that debates the very philosophies behind why in the world anyone should buy anything? 
What I learned from my parents not buying me this game as a child is that while reviews and popularity of something can be helpful in determining if something will be enjoyable to you, it shouldn't be the only factor in your decision to buy. Buy games you like, buy games others don't, and just play them. Elden Ring might be shit to one person, and some people loved Fallout 76 when it came out. Just have fun, do what you want, but don't let the crowd get ya down.
Anyways, Machinarium is great and you should play it! Bye bye!

148223846.review:
[b]*Conditional recommendation only*[/b]
You will need to survive a longish space-invaders arcade game about midway. If that isn't within your skillset, you will be irrevocably stuck. And the puzzles are hard and convoluted. 
If that's your thing, then, sure, go for it  :-)
If not, then be warned  :-(

This game gets a lot of cred., and I like both the story and how it looks. And it is wonderfully imaginative and I like the steampunk and odd characters. But it can be seriously obtuse - like : 'fix the power, to get electricity to a line, and get the cat to electrocute-stun itself, to carry down several stairs, to stuff into a pipe, to scare out a mouse, to make the music swing, to make a neighbour throw down a radio, that breaks and pick up a part inside, to ??'... or something like that, I may have got it jumbled a bit ... ;-)  There's a ton of stuff like that. Many places it's just about impossible to know what you have to do, to get what you need, to achieve...ehmm, what exactly ? Many items or interactable zones are almost impossible to see hidden in the scenery or background. And many of the puzzles are really hard. Plus the fact that the character has 3 different height levels and some (many) interactions will only accept if he's at some specific height otherwise he just stands there shaking his head. Luckily there are step-by-step guides to hand, the in-game hint is ok but also playthroughs and walkthrough guides by players. Without them I wouldn't even have been able cross that first drawbridge. 

As someone who is absolutely useless at arcade games, a space invaders challenge played to the level of points-gathering required here is way beyond my skillset. Therefore utterly stuck at about halfway-ish in the game. And had to resort to guides again and again even to get that far.

So - am now uninstalling and feeling rather disappointed. OK so I am obviously too stoopid and too slow for this game. But it would have been nice if they had included an easier mode or just simply a SKIP function for those of us in the casual-and-slow category.

--------
[15/10: Just some language edits for clarity]

148117897.review:
An absolute blast of a game! The story is given entirely visually, and I loved peicing together exactly what went down in Funky Robot Town(tm). The whole vibe of the game is SUPER charming too; the art is whimsical and eerie with a hand-drawn Tim Burton-esque feel, and the music is unique for each little room and puzzle.

Speaking of, the puzzles are just easy enough that you can figure them out yourself quite well, but also juuuuust hard enough that a few were real head-scratchers; when you DO get stumped, there's a fantastic hint system built in that a) requires some extra effort access (cute mini-game) and b) is still vague enough that you have to puzzle out how the hints can help with your particular puzzle. Every time I got a bit stuck (and I DID get stuck a few times), the hints were real handy at nudging me in the right direction.

Overall, a weird and wonderful lil' game, perfect for anyone who likes puzzlers or robots!

148087143.review:
Machinarium is a charming and gorgeous looking adventure game. The game has a few new tricks up it´s sleeve. For example, you can only interact with objects which are close and there are no spoken dialogue at all. I like the idea of explaining story and dialogue with just clever animations and symbols.

However, I think a little too much, the game requires you to  solve complex geometric puzzles on panels. If you are not skilled and like those kind of puzzles (think Rubik´s Cube) you might get stuck on a few of those. Also, the game was a little too short and the ending a little anticlimactic.

On a scale of 10, I would rate Machinarium an 8.

But I'll be back in the game again, even if it's just to watch Josef jam with the band.

This game was my childhood so I may be a bit biased.
I saw it was on sale the other day and thought I'd give one of my childhood games a shot, and through all the nostalgia, this is a pretty good puzzle game.
It took me these 6 hours to complete, I never searched the internet for anything, if you get stuck you can complete a minigame and just straight up get the answer, if you're into that.
All the puzzles make sense and theres not really any difficulty spike.
The world looks amazing, and is really lively with all the moving parts, all the characters and all the tiny cleaning robots, I love the tiny cleaning robots :3
Story does not take up a lot in this title though, it's a simple, cute story, with adorable protagonists.
All in all this is 100% a recommend if you're into puzzle games, it's simply just a stunning game.
Strong 9/10

147187884.review:
One of My Most Cherished Games - 
Easily the most calming and visually appealing point & click puzzler I have ever played. The art style is reminiscent of children's books I had when I was younger, and the dreary aesthetic with distant (almost hopeful) lighting gives it such a particular feeling. Although the puzzles do not change, the nostalgic feel of the game and world brings me to re-download it annually and play it with a cup of my favorite tea in-hand as holiday tradition. The variety of puzzles makes your initial play-through very entertaining, and the story element is small but a nice treat once you come to it. My only wish is that some add-on or DLC could expand the world from that external lift and I could see more of the Machinarium world!

147171573.review:
Un must play de toda la vida, la curva de dificultad (en terminos de puzzles y la "logica de point and click") se nota una curva considerable a medida vamos avanzando en la trama, no es muy corto pero tampoco tan largo y el juego te va llevando un poco de la mano con pistas leves en el entorno pero tambien pistas mas directas que solo nos dicen que hay que hacer, es bueno saber que los desarrolladores sabrian que en algun punto te puedes quedar atascado y por eso pusieron una guia que puedes consultar en cualquier momento siempre y cuando completes el minijuego que trae (algo largo al parecer), lo cual le suma puntos y ayuda a que realmente quieras pasartelo bien con este juego.

La musica es bastante buena y hay canciones que facilmente descargaria no mas para escucharla de lo que me han gustado, puede que sean algo cortas y repetitivas pero no realmente molestas.

No te vas a perder de nada a medida que avanzas asi que es practicamente imposible quedar bloqueado en algun punto, aunque entre mas terreno se te abra mas dificil sera darte cuenta de ese minusculo objeto que no viste que era necesario para continuar.

lo unico negativo es que el juego no tiene guardado automatico para lo lineal que es, cosa que te puede putear un poco si de repente se te crashea por A o B motivo y debes volver a recorrer todo el tramo y resolver los puzzles que perdiste en esa parte

pero que mas se puede decir, es un juego que vas a platinar SI O SI y eso me gusta, bastante casual friendly para aquellos que ya estan traumados (como yo) con supuestos logros que te fuerzan a jugar el juego otras 10 horas para conseguir todos los logros porque x objeto era perdible y etc

un mundo que deja preguntas a medida lo vas explorando y quisieras saber un poco mas sobre el, aunque al final cierra con broche de oro con un final satisfactorio

Un must play para los amantes de los point and click

I'm gonna start this off by saying this is a great game and that people think that giving a "I don't recommend" = "this game is objectively bad".

Point & Click games usually are about looking around, finding stuff and using it to progress. In this game there's also puzzles that are mathematical. You need to observe, find the pattern and solve it. If this is what you're looking for, go for it, but it's not what I'm looking for in a Point & Click game.

Despite this issue, what really made me refund this game is that atmosphere. There's none. I couldn't connect with this game like I could with The Dig or Amerzone. And the levels feels like just another stage of puzzles. It felt like those 90's games for children to learn how to think and how to use a computer that we used to have in school. So I can't recommend this.

146664532.review:
[h1]WHY DID I WAIT SO LONG TO PLAY THIS ROBOTIC GEM?[/h1]
I have had [b]Machinarium[/b] in my library for quite some time, and that was after it sat on my wishlist for ages. I loved the Samarost series, but it didn't dawn on me that this game was by the same developer, Amanita Design, until I finally started playing the game and began noticing the similarities.
 
Believe it or not, this is a Love Story...well, technically, it is a robotic love story! I am still amazed that this developer is able to tell a story from beginning to end without a single word being spoken! Every character Josef the robot meets has a backstory they happily share with him via a thought bubble, and Josef somehow manages to help them all overcome their plights as he overcomes obstacles on his own journey.
 
This adorable robot has a few tricks up his metallic sleeve. He can grow taller or squish himself until he's practically flat. When he comes across an inventory item, he simply eats it; okay, technically, he just stores the items in his tin can belly. If you try to get him to do something or go somewhere off-limits, he will shake his head vehemently, so don't try to convince him otherwise.
 
The puzzles, at times, were maddening! I played the Tic-Tac-Toe game (place 5 nuts/bolts in a row) multiple times before finally beating my opponent. (the trick was to place my pieces away from the beaten path, so to speak, while leaving a gap because the AI could only block one end.
 
I loved the two Arcade Games, even though it was annoying to have to pedal an exercise bike to recharge the generator after each failed attempt. The first Arcade game was Space Invaders, where you had to score 1000 points by shooting all of the invaders without getting shot too many times, which ended the game. The second Arcade Game is a sliding box puzzle where you have to use directional arrows to move a blue dot into various boxes to move them until you place the smaller blue box into the larger blue box and then guide the boxes out of the gate, which opens once the two boxes are combined. This is repeated 5 times, with each puzzle being slightly more progressive than its predecessor.
 
My advice is to pay attention to all the thought bubbles and look for puzzle clues that are usually nearby. Most of the door or machine puzzle instructions are just simple patterns that need to be set, such as selecting a series of lamp lights.
 
After completing this adventure, you feel like you actually accomplished something because it isn't always easy to figure out what you are supposed to do and why you're doing it. Eventually, you get that Aha! moment, and it makes you feel like a robotic genius, loll! I really wish I had played this game sooner!
 
Check out my Group/Curator page  at https://steamcommunity.com/groups/thewoodsforum
and don't forget to stop by my nature-themed chat forum at https://thewoodsforum.boards.net/

145029850.review: Very sweet game, where you solve some problems and puzzles while soaking in a cute robot story and amazing atmosphere. All the screens are hand drawn in an inspired, thoughtful way, with multiple motion elements (steam, flies, flickering sparks, etc.) to make the world come to life. There's a backstory narrative that emerges through progressive bits of robot memory, like a good cartoon or indie-animation movie. THE MUSIC AND AMBIENT SOUND IS AMAZING. Thank Tomas Dvorak (aka Floex) for creating an album's-worth of wonderful stand-alone-worthy music for this game. I kid you not, the music is on the level of great movie soundtracks or Pink Floyd/Brian Eno/Tron/etc. imaginative music. This is an A+++ game for me. There's a bit of an intentional 8-bit retro feel or homage to it, and some of the puzzles are much harder than others. There's actually a love story that emerges, as well as villains who, if you do everything right, might just get exactly what they deserve. My biggest complaint about this game is that the producers have not made a sequel.

143479001.review:
I first heard about Machinarium a decade or so ago.  A new neighbor who was walking by glanced toward my patio because he noticed movement, realized I was playing a video game, and then later that evening, he knocked on my door because he wanted to introduce himself to his "cool" neighbors.  Over the course of the conversation, he mentioned Machinarium.  I had just picked it up in an indie games bundle, but I hadn't paid too much attention to it.  I tried it out that evening, and then life happened and I'm just now returning to it.  Thanks for the recommendation, Joe.  Let's do the compliment sandwich this time.

Machinarium's visuals are gorgeous.  I like the funky, kind of cartoony feel where important things kind of stand out as opposed to the slightly more muted background.  Most of the robots have interesting designs (particularly the saxophone player), and the least interesting character to look at is actually Josef, the main robot.  The backgrounds have a soft, almost hand-drawn look to them, and there's a lot going on in town.

Controls are simple, but can be annoying.  I used a controller (DualShock 4), but I think a keyboard and mouse may have been better in this situation.  I found myself trying several times to click one object, or combine an object with something else, only for Josef to shake his head because he thought I was trying to do something else.  The final sequence with Berta was the most annoying.  During mini games, though, the controller was fine.  Space Invaders with a PS4 controller was a first for me.

Finally, the soundscape is wonderful.  Admittedly, a lot of the sound effects themselves were forgettable, but the music will stick with me for a while.  I'd purchase just the soundtrack to have playing in the background as I work or study.  It's beautiful and soft, and it fits right in with the game's overall feel in ways that many soundtracks fall short.

I wouldn't purchase the game at full price, but it's definitely worth a look if you can catch it on sale.  3.5/5

142539976.review:
Machinarium is a beautifully crafted game. There is no reading involved, and the story is told entirely visually either through interacting with the world or through short animations played within comic strip style thought bubbles. The puzzles are simple but engaging (sometimes frustrating, but you may not be thinking logically enough)

The atmosphere, music, and sounds are crafted with care and all extremely cohesive. There is never something used simply for the sake of it. Everything has a purpose; and for a 2D game, there is a rather good sense of depth. You can interact with many things in the world indirectly. This is a living place.

If you get stuck, there is a hint guide and a walkthrough built in to the game. These consist of hand drawn illustrations (much like the game's presentation itself), which are designed to loosely lead you in the right direction if you get stuck. It's done in a clever way that allows you to keep the satisfaction of solving the puzzles for yourself and mostly functions as a way of avoiding breaking the flow.

Play it once. You won't regret it. It only takes a few hours. It has aged like a fine wine.

142146194.review:
Machinarium is a cool-looking point n click adventure, by the devs that made the Samarost games.

You play as a robot aiming to figure out why he got exiled out of the city. You meet bad guys, good guys and everything in the between on your journey. The gameplay is pretty standard with various puzzles, item hunting and even some mini games (some harders than others!). While some item puzzles can be tricky or not make too much sense, they are usually straight forward and there aren't really any dead ends.

The art design is very unique, and different from the Samorost series, this looks more like a family friendly version of HH Geiger's artwork. The soundtrack is pretty good and fits in where it should. This game continues the Amanita tradition of not having any voice acting, instead telling things through the environment, odd sounds and speak bubbles with drawn objects in them.

I definitely recommend this as a point n click game for both fans of the genre and beginners. I'm honestly surprised this game never got a sequel, but I'm excited to play more titles from the developers' catalogue of games!

141841483.review:
[h1]Machinarium[/h1]
At first you'll think that you are an idiot, but after completing the game, you'll consider yourself [strike]still an idiot[/strike] a genius.
[b]Gameplay[/b]
Machinarium is a point and click adventure game, which is completed in the old "click all items you have against everything on screen until something happens". It's a tale of a little robo-buddy who will become your friend for the next 5 hours. [5 hours of brainstorming]
[b]Puzzles[/b]
The puzzles in this game are perfectly balanced. Some of them can be obvious, but some can be really mind-blowing. Thanks to developers, there is a hint system in a game, which is also good. It doesn't give you an answer, but only suggests a "solution".
[b]Art-style[/b]
Machinarium has one of the most unique styles ever. The game is from 2009, but still looks decent. Every screen is a painting which you can look at for hours.
[b]Conclusion[/b]
I'd highly recommend this game for puzzle-lovers. A small adventure for one evening, which you'll definitely remember for a long time.

[b]7 Nuts 'n' Bolts out of 10[/b]

Puzzles can be largely divided into two categories.

One involves informing you of the rules and making you explore how to apply these rules to produce a predetermined result.

The other involves hiding the rules and making you find out what rules are hidden.

This game falls under the second category.

As a game, it's well made, but unfortunately, I prefer puzzles of the former type, so it's hard for me to enjoy this game.

Just now, for instance, I found out what I needed to do was reach up and down to make an owl break a highline so I could tie it to a banister and electrocute a cat in order to stuff it in a didgeridoo so that a lady would throw a radio out the window.  Don't even know why I need to the radio either.  

The straw that broke the camel's back though was finding out I'd apparently soft-locked the game by messing with a clock puzzle the wrong way.  I even downloaded a save file someone else provided on the game's forums so this evidently isn't that unusual, but all that only to find out the devs patched the game to where there's no longer a way to import it.  I'm cutting my losses and moving on.

I'd say buy the soundtrack or maybe a print of the art but leave it to someone else to actually play the thing.

139205020.review:
Great look, great OST, more trail and error vs point and click due to the low quality puzzles and poor engine. 
Puzzles are decidedly obtuse, only beaten on "How in actual was I meant to work out that?" from the utterly dumbfoundedly stupid Deponia series.

Packed full of design flaws that were known and sorted years ago.
For instance: "Colour design on the tic-tac-toe" where the opposition uses the same colour as you, making it difficult to see what is going on. 

The Tic-Tac-Toe minigame is also 100% programmed as a tic-tac-toe game and ALWAYS goes first. If you know your tic-tac-toe you know this puts the player in an "draw at best"  position the majority of the time - and this is pure chance on where the game decides to put the first marker.
Also, after the great frustration, the 5 in a Row achievement is also glitched so doesn't even unlock. 5 games, 6, games, then 7 in a row... didn't unlock. 

There's also a general navigation problem of "use this with this": No, that doesn't work. 
"Ok, I'll manually march you over there and then use it": oh wow, look it works. 
Because other designers worked out this was crap this doesn't appear in other P&C games, and only ensures the player is wasting their time, therefore you also have to get into the habit of walking up to random crap just to see if that's the magic thing you're meant to be interacting with.

The major thing tho is "how did the creators of Samorost come so unstuck on this?"
There's a great game in amongst the poor implementation.

Recommended, but at a discounted price.
 
First off, just like any similar game, do yourself a favor and do not watch any videos or streams of someone else playing this. You are only going to take away from your own experience. It is a bit short, but not terribly like I've seen with similar puzzle games... but it won't do it any justice by spoiling content.

This is a set of Interesting puzzles presented in an interesting world. A couple of the puzzles are more challenging and require some effort. In general, this is mostly easy to complete.  No part of this game is fast-paced action. It is simply focusing on the details of the environment and figuring out what needs to be done to progress.
 
Being that this game is a finite set of puzzles, the replayability is low. Once you beat it, there really isn't a reason to play again unless so many years have gone by that you've forgotten everything. With some games in the genre, the achievements help keep players interested longer and sometimes for additional playthroughs. This is not the case here as I believe most of the achievements cannot be missed.

I stumbled across this game a couple of days ago and remembered when my Mom used to sit and play this with me when I was young. So naturally I bought the game and I don't regret it one bit. The opening, music and animations took me right back, the atmosphere of this game is so lovely and meticulously crafted. I'm not the biggest fan of puzzle games but these puzzles were great. There were a couple of really difficult solutions you had to really pay attention to in order to get, but those were few and far between. Even with some of the more confusing puzzles, the music and atmosphere of the game entices you to keep going. The puzzles get harder as you go on, requiring more thinking outside of the box, but the transition from somewhat obvious puzzles to more obscure puzzles is seamless and buttery smooth. That first "Ah ha!" moment is so satisfying, and it only gets better as time goes on. I highly suggest the game, its one of the best I've played in terms of atmosphere and sheer artistry, as well as Amanita's other games, my Mother and I are very fond of them. 

Also! If you sit and go afk, you'll see some adorable little daydreams from our lovely Robot Josef :)

136173625.review:
Machinarium no es la mejor aventura gráfica point and click que he jugado, ni tiene los puzzles más ingeniosos y difíciles que he jugado, pero sin duda es de las más simpáticas y amenas que he terminado. 
El juego entra por los ojos a primera vista, con unos fondos dibujados con mucho mimo que, pese a ser bastante estáticos, están cargados de detalle.
El juego no tiene ni un solo diálogo de historia, ni hablado ni escrito (no han tenido que gastar mucho en traducciones), y lo poco que se cuenta es mediante imágenes, incluidos los diferentes puzzles que nos propondrá el juego. No es algo malo, pero en algún puzzle no te quedará del todo claro que es lo que se espera que hagamos, no obstante a poco que le des otra vuelta entenderás que se espera de ti. Además, el juego tiene dos tipos de pistas, una un poco más básica que explica la idea general de lo que debes hacer, y otra mucho más completa, la cual es directamente una guía integrada en el juego, que explica paso a paso que debes hacer. Para acceder a esta guía, hay que abrir un libro que siempre tendremos en la esquina del inventario, el cual está cerrado con llave y hay que superar un minijuego para abrirle. Es una manera original de incorporarlo, aunque no soy partidario de su inclusión, reconozco que la he usado en 1 o 2 sitios.
Tampoco abusan mucho del "Pixel Hunting" propio de muchas aventuras gráficas (sobre todo de los 90), y básicamente con algo de observación veremos qué objetos son manipulables (gracias al detalle de sus escenarios y buen diseño artístico).

El juego lo he jugado íntegramente en la Steam Deck, la cual es perfecta para esta clase de juegos, ya que gracias a los trackpads el uso del ratón es comodísimo, igual que utilizar un ratón.

133330299.review:
Oh my circuits! Beep – beep! Welcome to Machinaruim, my dear fella! Now, I invite you to this point-and-click adventure game developed by talented guys from Amanita games, that is one of the most adorable and visually captivating games I’ve ever played!

From the moment I launched the game I was whisked away to a quaint place of robots, machinery, and industrial landscapes, all rendered in stunning detail. The land-dawn graphics are simply lovely, with intricate elements and charming animations that bring the word to life. The game’s art style is reminiscent of a children’s picture book, with a muted colour palette and a soft, dreamlike vibe. The sound effects in the game are a symphony of whimsical robot noises from gentle whirring of gears to the satisfying clicks and clacks of buttons and levers, with each robot in the game having its own unique set of noises that convey its personality and quirk.

But it’s not just aesthetics that make Machinarium so special. The game is also a delight to play! As you guide your robot protagonist through the winding paths, you deal with multi-layered mini-missions that require a bit of exploration and experimentation to solve. They range from logic puzzles, to dialogue ones where you need to decipher the intentions of other characters. The puzzles are integrated seamlessly into the world, it clues hidden in the environment and clever twists that keep you on your toes.

In a nutshell, Machinaruim is an absolute gem of a game that I would recommend anyone who chooses not only meticulously crafted universes but also touching stories. With its nostalgic touch and a meditative walkthrough, it’s a true work of art that is sure to delight players of all ages.

133237713.review:

131105537.review:
It all starts with a view of an odd looking and densely built city located in a vast wasteland. A garbage disposal robot is flying out from the centre of the city to a junkyard where it empties its contents, including a set of parts for a small robot. This robot is controlled by the player, and it has to first reassemble itself before it can return to the city to make things right. However, there is a group of bully robots with other ideas of fun.

The cute little story in Machinarium mostly serves as a background to solving a varied set of puzzles. Some of them are based on the often a bit far-fetched type that is expected from traditional point-and-click games, and others are more like mini games within the game. The actual background to the story is uncovered as the game goes on, and it is not obvious at all to start with. This is also a good motivation to continue playing. The player wants to know more in addition to solve the larger issues created by the bullies.

Machinarium has a very distinct artistic design. Both the graphical style and the music are very enjoyable. In addition, there is no dialogue at all in the game except animated thought bubbles and the body language of the interacting robots. This can sometimes make it a bit unclear where to go and what needs to be done. There is a built-in hint system that can aid in those situations, and also when the puzzle solutions are too obscure for the player.

I liked the game for its style and its atmosphere. Sometimes I felt a bit frustrated when a puzzle did not want to be solved, but it mostly had to do with a bit of inexactness in the point-and-click part. Some things can only be interacted with if the robot is standing at the right place, and that can be difficult to spot. That is only a minor issue in an otherwise great little game.

129377905.review:
I played this game years ago but never finished it (I think it was bundled with another game). I picked it up again on sale and played through it in one evening. It is rather short but beautifully crafted, from the graphics to the music to the puzzle mini games which were my personal highlight. Also the nonverbal storytelling deserves praise. The only gripe I have is that you have to walk to every point of interest before you can interact with it.
I paid about four bucks and had a blast. If you are new to point and click adventures or puzzle games then maybe play something else first. I think this game is one of the harder point and click adventures I've played.

129366453.review:
This adventure game is a little gem and truly a work of art. Technically, it has the merit of being both simple and beautiful, especially for the 2D graphics looks hand drawn (probably it is) and the ambient soundtrack, but with some very catchy tunes where they need to be. Also, the fact that nobody speaks contributes to the minimalistic style: concepts are instead communicated through beatutiful drawings and animations. The puzzles are not trivial but fair and based on solid logic for the most part.
I would say that what really sets this game apart from the classics in the adventure game genre (Monkey Island et all) is the abundant presence of logic based minigames and the fact that you never really find yourself with more than 3 or 4 items in your inventory. It also comes with an integrated tips system that should help whenever the player gets stuck.
I really recommend this game to everybody, but I believe that the fact that the puzzles are not as dispersive as others in this genre makes it very well suited also for first timers.

128829436.review:
This is a very difficult game requiring not only good puzzle game awareness (important to sense "maybe I need another item for this level") and raw puzzle solving skills. However it is very well designed as every single possible interaction has a purpose. Nothing is extraneous. I enjoy the music a lot, the quality is amazing. The art quality is amazing too. The story is one of oppression, discrimination and the triumph of the common spirit. It is only hinted, and in a lighthearted way, but that adds another layer of humanity to this game. (There was a scene about smoking cigarette that the tall guys were not happy about for no reason and they were so scared and hide the cigarette when they walk by - that resonated with me deeply)

Only thing is: this game is hard, for better or worse. Mild spoiler: there will be a time when you have to play the five-in-a-row version of tik tac toe and the game's program was so good I thought it was meant to be unbeatable, as a result I skipped it and I spent so much time wondering what is the next step, when in fact it is right undr my nose... When I googled online sources and learned it was beatable, I was in disbelief and it still took me a few dozen tries to get past!! My advice is "don't play tight or meta," play a bit "weird" and make your early moves a bit spaced-out; that seemed to confuse the bot enough and gave me a win. The program is flawless when it comes to usual close range attacking moves.

128349406.review:
I can't tell if Machinarium is smart-cute or stupid-cute -- but I got it at 80% off, which was definitely smart-cute. It's not so outstanding as you might figure from a 96% "Overwhelmingly Positive" score, but there's nothing in it that would make me not recommend it. The puzzles are basic recycled content that you find in all "point-n-click puzzlers" (my name for games of this genre): good puzzles that don't necessarily diminish from replaying. The art and setting are 'gorgey', memorable and well-styled. The point-n-click stuff was the most frustrating part and made me require the in-game hints/walkthrough, as there's a surprising amount hidden in details; what I call smart-cute. As for the story, it's very, very stupid-cute.

To summarize, it's a game a kid will like (or, anyone who doesn't have a name for a whole genre of games like it), and it's a game like a kid: sometimes quickly irritating, but mostly very charming, funny, and eager to look at the world in a new way. And cute.

In my opinion this issue is not solvable at the hint system level, puzzles should't require brute force or an over the top level of pattern recognition to be accessible. The hints are there to compensate for bullshit puzzles. Take out the bullshit puzzles and the hints are no longer needed.

126899450.review:
Timeless yet feels a bit... dated, in a slightly ironic way. Once again this game compares most closely to environmental puzzlers where the narrative drives the game, because well - that's what it is. As such Limbo and Inside from PlayDead are obvious comparisons, albeit not entirely fair as Machinarium is quite a bit older than both.

The atmosphere in this game blew me away, and is, quite possibly, the primary attraction here. The sound design and art style blend together very well in a somewhat bleak but oddly wholesome world I would love to see more of. The story is minimal but compliments the tone of the game perfectly. The game presents itself very well.

The puzzles are... a bit of a mixed bag. There are some pretty classic ones like tic-tac-toe versus a literal bot, or rotation disc puzzles - but the game clearly takes most pride in the far-fetched comical ones that require you to set in motion a cartoon-like sequence of actions to proceed. Multiple issues arise on this front: it's definitely not always clear what the player can interact with, some of the interactions take forever to complete (very slow animations) and, by far the worst offender in my opinion, a lot of them are not at all isolated. The latter requires some elaboration: Machinarium divides the world in static sections that need to be "solved" in some way, but the game frequently incorporates elements from previous sections in future ones. This obfuscates problem solving horrendously as, if the player so happens to have missed a previous item, it is not incorporated in their thought process. It's quirky and adds a feeling of progression I suppose, but as far as the puzzles themselves go this doesn't make them any clearer or more satisfying to solve. Aforementioned games, and then especially Inside do this a lot better by isolating the puzzle to a specific area.

Machinarium is a great game with an excellent atmosphere but slightly awkward puzzle implementation.

124913198.review:
First time playing. I finished the game in a few sessions with a total time of 5.2 hours. I only needed a couple of hints. Would I reecommend? Yes.

[b]Things I liked[/b]
- Music was really good, I just wish there was a way to adjust volume in game.
- The 2d / minigame puzzles were really good. But were almost entirely disconnected from anything in the world. This is a pretty short list of "things I liked," but really, the minigame puzzles are really good.
- The world puzzle / adventuring was ok. Not as good as the minigame puzzles, but fun.
- Lots of variety to the puzzles.

[b]Things that were ehhhh[/b]
- The inventory system. I don't know if there's a better way to do this, but I found myself frequently pulling things out of my inventory and blindly clicking around hoping for something to interact with.
- The hint system was pretty useless. The times I needed a hint to figure out what to do, I was already trying to do what the hint told me. For example, rescuing pink umbrella lady's dog, I knew I needed [spoiler]to shoot the string gun to pull him across the pond[/spoiler], I just didn't know [spoiler]what I was missing (the plunger)[/spoiler]. The only other place I got stuck was the owl. I guess the "hint" is that the owl sort of interacts with you, so you have to figure that out, but I missed that (and the hint for that screen is about the cat).
- The story / plot was confusing, in that you (the main character) lacked coherency. The start of the game implies you are a pile of junk with no back story (maybe?). And then later you find kitchen girl, and you two become immediately attached for some reason? The shallow depth of the villains is at least forgivable, their purpose in the story-telling is direct and clear.

[b]Things I disliked[/b]
- The minigames (not 2d/minigame puzzles). [spoiler]The space invaders game, and the maze game[/spoiler] at the end.
- The "crafting" aspect of your inventory, with no hint about what can or should be combined.
- Not being able to cancel an action, especially starting a long walk sequence to transition to another screen when I was trying to click on a location on the current screen.
- Not knowing what I can interact with. I got stuck and had to check a walkthrough to find out [spoiler]I needed to click the camouflaged plunger in the jail cell because I didn't see it[/spoiler].
- Having to repeat the same sequence multiple times. Escaping the sewer and [spoiler]grabbing the jailer's key[/spoiler], having to [spoiler]get the oil hose run to the outdoor elevator machine[/spoiler], having to re-solve the indoor elevator to go to a particular level.
- Not being able to backtrack 1) at the indoor elevator door to the walkway up to "the city". Have to climb up the pipe and enter at the top again. 2) Not being able to backtrack, but can follow an earlier sequence to get back to a point, like the long path around to the outdoor elevator, so back tracking is "allowed" but not easy.
- The clock "puzzle." I still feel like I'm missing something. There were so many times listed in the city.

[quote][b] One of the best point & click games of all time. Hard puzzles, beautiful art style, and an amazing soundtrack. I really recommend everyone try it out.[/b][/quote]
[h2] Features: [/h2]
• [b][u] Puzzles[/u][/b] - I have played Machinarium before (about 8 years ago) and decided to do it again for nostalgia. Lucky for me, I have forgotten everything about the puzzles and challenged myself this time with to play no guides and hints. Wow, they were quite hard to do, even the mini-games. At some of them, I was stuck for a whole hour.
• [b][u] Visuals[/u][/b] - I loved so much the hand-drawn steampunk art-style, truly memorable. One can say a picture is worth a thousand words, and it is true for Machinarium. This is one of the few games that manages to deliver the story and the emotions through the drawings. I was so inspired by It that some of the characters I have drawn myself.
• [b][u] Soundtrack[/u][/b] - Sadly, I'm a person that most of the time doesn't notice the music in the game. Frankly, not here. The melody is so relaxing and beautiful, contributing to creative thinking as you play. Sometimes I just paused and listened to it.
• [b][u] Length[/u][/b] -If you play with no hints, it can take about 6-8 hours to complete, and otherwise a lot less.

[quote] Get Machinarium on sale if you want a good point & click game[/quote]

If you liked my review, check [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/yankoro223/recommended/] other reviews[/url] in my profile or follow my page: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42670199-Lisko-reviews/] Lisko Reviews[/url]

122487691.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- I love the style of the game. It feels like I'm playing a watercolor painting
- The character designs are also great. Lots of personality despite being robots
- The music is pretty good, but not very memorable

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- The story is very simple: you're a little robot trying to save your friend from captivity
- The game is very relaxing despite the plot. It's easy to take your time and get lost in the little visual details

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- It's a point-and-click adventure game, and the gameplay doesn't break that mold very often
- Some of the puzzles are pretty devious, but exploration, intuition, and trying different things will usually get you there in the end
- I don't think any of the achievements are missable, so it's pretty simple to 100% this game. As such, there's not a lot to motivate a replay

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- It's an easy game to recommend to adventure game enthusiasts. Others may find the simple plot and focus on puzzles to be a little dry
- Ran flawlessly on the Steam Deck

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]7.5/10[/b]. A fun, pretty little game. It should only take a few hours to 100% it

[h1] AT A GLANCE [/h1]
(Full review follows below)

[list]
[*][b] Game Name: [/b] Machinarium
[*][b] Original Release: [/b] 2009-10-16
[*][b] Genre Tags: [/b] Adventure, Point & Click
[*][b] Estimated Playtime (Campaign): [/b] 2-4 hours
[*][b] 100% Achievements Playtime: [/b] 2-4 hours
[*][b] DLC Required for 100% Achievements: [/b] N/A
[*][b] Multiplayer Aspect: [/b] None
[*][b] Replayability: [/b] Some
[*][b] Recommended To: [/b] Achievement Hunters, Puzzle Story Lovers
[/list]

[h1] REVIEW [/h1]
[b] Machinarium [/b] is a point & click, adventure game.  

A small robot is sent to a scrap heap. How he got there and what he needs to do all unfold as you play the story and see flashbacks. 

The game is moderately difficult and some puzzles may require you to look up a guide if you are not used to the game genre. Play time is ~2-4 hours to complete the story and to get all achievements. There is some replayability to this game much like most adventure games.  There could be additional ways to solve puzzles, interactions you missed, or just reliving the story again. I recommend the game to anyone who loves classic 90’s adventure games or is an achievement hunter.

This is the game that sold me on point and click adventures entirely. I am stuck chasing after the dragon of another experience that can match it. 

The art style is exceptional, and consistent throughout. Each new room is a treat to find. Moreover though, the little touches are what make this game shine. The music and sound design match up perfectly to give the experience a very warming feel throughout, such that it's easy to "fall into" the room and puzzles therein. Some rooms did have me stuck for a good while, but the art and music makes it feel not quite so much as if you are stuck, but rather lost for a while in it's world.

The puzzles are difficult, but not overmuch so. And there is a neat in built game mechanic to provide tips when you need them, and a solution as well if you absolutely have to have it. This saves having to jump out of the game and break immersion. 

Beautiful game.

118375592.review:
This review is specially made for those who like to get all the achievements and have this game in their backlog (minor spoilers ahead).

[b]Description:[/b]  
Machinarium is a point and click puzzle game where you control a little robot that has to solve puzzles by interacting with objects and certain points on the backgrounds. The graphics are all hand drawn and have a steampunk theme. 

[b]Achievements:[/b]  
[b]How many:[/b] 12 Achievements, most are obtained by solving the puzzles and finishing the game. 
[b]How much time:[/b] Around 3 hours, if you don’t get stuck for long. I’ve spent more than 20 hours on the game but I played it several times and didn’t use a guide.
[b]Game difficulty:[/b] Easy, the solution for a few puzzles isn’t very obvious but after a few tries, you will most likely solve them. Guides are available too.
[b]Achievements’ Difficulty:[/b] Easy. You only need to complete the puzzles and do a few additional tasks that aren’t very hard to complete.

[b]Overall opinion:[/b]  
This is one of my favorite point and click games. The hand drawn graphics are very well drawn and detailed and the characters and their animations are cute and funny to look at. The game itself isn’t hard so it can be enjoyed by everyone, including children.


[b]Join and follow my group Ribbon Hunters for more suggestions and reviews of easy indie games to get all the achievements:[/b] https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42556190-Ribbon-Hunters/

117562013.review:
I've been meaning to play this one for a while, and while i am glad to have finally gotten around to it, i feel that it is not quite as good as other point and click adventures I've played since first seeing this game. it is missing some quality of life mechanics that i have since come to expect:

clicking on a distant hotspot wit an item should move the character to the hotspot and then use the item, in this game you need to walk up to the hotspot and then use the item.
double clicking on a screen exit should automatically transition to the next screen.
being able to press a button to reveal hotspots would have been nice to in some cases.

some other issues i had with this game:
some screen exits aren't as noticeable as they could be, resulting in me taking the long way around instead of the way im expected to go. in regards to the elevator, i should be able to go back into the elevator from the staircase, as that is the most obvious way back up to the previous floor and there is no indication that I shouldn't be able to do so. this also goes for some actions that need to be taken, like what you need to do with the cat once you get it, as one example.
the height adjustment mechanic is featured prominently in the first section of the game, but once you reach the more
nonlinear second half, it doesn't feel like it gets as much use.

with all that being said i still very much enjoyed Machinarium, its presentation was top notch, the graphic style is nice, the little animations that play every now and then are adorable, and the music is wonderful to listen to. And I especially liked the way the story was slowly revealed and Josef's interactions with Berta

116737606.review:
This is a very broken version of the game. It's a shame because when I played this on Playstation back in the day I really enjoyed it. Seeing it on Steam recently I wanted to play it through again and get the achievements BUT over an hour of trying to fix the problems with this game I've decided to just give up and cut my losses. In the support section for this game, the devs stated back in 2017 they were aware of this issue and would look into it. 5 years later and there's no response, no update, no fix....

The game will run unbelievably slow to the point where you have to check the Task Manager to see what the hell is going on. It only takes 100k-ish of RAM, meaning it's not very intense on your rig but it plays like your PC is falling apart at the seams.

If you change the volume through Windows then it will just automatically put the volume back to maximum. I've never seen that in a game before, interesting choice from the devs... I don't understand the thinking behind it. It's up to me what volume I play the game at, not the devs.

The mouse keeps de-syncing too. When you start the game up, or minimize and maximize the game, or change window it snaps the 'game' mouse back to the centre of the screen when your actual mouse isn't on that spot. This means when you click on certain places the game gets confused and starts showing some weird splash screen when you're just trying to click the menus, the items etc.

£12.99 for such a broken game, that is around 15 years old now... it's daylight robbery. I don't mind too much if the game actually works but this is just taking the piss out of customers.

Don't buy this game, spend your money on a developer that fixes their issues.

114186520.review:
[h1]Overall[/h1]

Machinarium is ok.  It will mostly appeal to those with some nostalgia for the old school style point and click adventure games of the 90's(like Space Quest or King's Quest).  I would rate the Space Quest and King's Quest games as superior but Machinarium has its own charm and a different vibe to it.  There's nothing profoundly new or unique about this game.  However the game flows just fine, has some interesting scenes with fitting ambiance, and I don't have any annoyances or complaints with it.

My favorite thing about this game was actually the soundtrack.  There's a few songs on there I liked enough to add to my playlists.  Since I was kind of medium on the game overall, this aspect was one that helped commit me to giving it a "recommended" rating.

If you like point and click adventure games, and the videos/screenshots are appealing to you, it's probably worth your time.  However, I wouldn't rate this as an absolute "must play" of the "point and click" genre.  Get it on sale if it sounds like something that interests you.  I got it for $4 and don't have any regrets.

[h1]Gameplay and difficulty[/h1]

At a high level this game is mostly a mix of "finding the right item" and solving various mind puzzles spread throughout the game, which is pretty typical for this genre.  Some of the mind puzzles can be complex and probably require at least a middle school mind or higher to figure out.  The mind puzzles primarily consist of maneuvering multiple objects in a confined space in order to obtain a desired configuration.  As an adult I found the game sufficiently challenging.  I had to stop a few times and come back with fresh thoughts another day to get by some areas.  At one point I got stuck and relented and looked for a hint online(don't worry, no spoilers ahead), only to realize I was only stuck because I made the wrong presumption about an object.  I thought this object was "view only" but it could actually be further manipulated. I just didn't try.  Kicked myself for that one.  None of the puzzles were too hard to solve.  They just required some time and thought.

[h1]How long is it?[/h1]

I completed it in 7.5 hours, which according to the game's leader board(measured by game time) puts me in the top 33% or so.  Decent length for the type of game it is, but maybe slightly on the shorter end when comparing to others of the same genre.

[h1]Good for kids?[/h1]

This game is one of the most kid friendly point and click adventure game I've seen.  And I'm not saying that because the game is easy.  The game definitely has some hard parts that will require a mature brain to figure out.  But its good if you have a young preschool age kid that just wants to watch as you play through it.  There is no text to read throughout the game.  All communication is done through animated cloud bubbles, so no reading is required.

There's not any violence in the game.  Just some bullies who you have to outwit and overcome.

[h1]Achievements[/h1]

The achievements are really straight forward.  They basically represent various milestones throughout the game, that are impossible to miss as you progress.  So if you complete the game you will have earned all achievements.

114004835.review:
El mundo de las aventuras gráficas es muy amplio y nos ha acompañado, sobre todo a los jugadores de PC, durante décadas, con juegos como “Monkey Island”, “King’s Quest”, “Grim Fandango” o “The Longest Journey”. Y, sin embargo, con el gran catálogo de aventuras gráficas que hay, Machinarium ha conseguido un hueco en mi corazón, no solo por lo que transmite, si no por lo que es a nivel técnico. 

En primer lugar, hablemos de la técnica. Ninguno de los personajes te habla mediante palabras; te hablan mediante una serie de historietas con dibujos (en ocasiones estáticos). Esto tiene una parte buena y otra mala. La buena es que la historia se siente poco densa, fácil de comprender en líneas generales y fluida. Pero, por otra parte, la libre interpretación y la falta de detalles en la historia no me dejó comprender los matices de los personajes, el porqué de la organización y, sobre todo, las motivaciones.

La búsqueda de los objetos es la típica en cualquier aventura de este estilo: clicar el mapa para rezar de que ese objeto un poco diferente sea lo que necesitas para el siguiente puzle. Pero es en los propios puzles donde Machinarium, en mi opinión, destaca. No son puzles de juntar objetos, de interactuar con el objeto del inventario con un NPC… son puzles lógicos, de mayor o menor dificultad, que te separan de la mecánica de “Aventura Gráfica” para llevarte a una de “Juego tipo Escape Room”. A mi juicio, es refrescante, y hace que las secciones estén muy bien cohesionadas, generando una muy buena sensación general.

Y por supuesto, no puedo hablar de la técnica sin hablar de las pistas que te ofrece el juego. Como Aventura Gráfica, es consciente de que los jugadores se van a ver atorados en alguna búsqueda o en algún puzle, así que genera pistas de dos maneras diferentes: en algunas localizaciones el icono de pista se activará, pudiendo darte un pequeño consejo, con la estética de dibujos, sobre lo siguiente que hacer; si lo anterior no es suficiente, podemos utilizar un libro, con un minijuego previo sencillo, que nos permite ver todas las acciones que habrá que hacer en el área (incluyendo las respuestas a los acertijos). Como alguien que se suele bloquear en este tipo de aventuras, este tipo de ayudas me vienen de perlas. Además, por la longitud del minijuego del libro, te planteas seriamente si utilizarlo.

Finalmente, sin hacer spoilers, decir que la historia me ha parecido tierna. Simple, sí, pero tierna, en un mundo lleno de posibilidades que me hubiese gustado explorar un poco más. El robot protagonista, que se llama Josef (me he enterado por los cromos), expresa muchísimo a pesar de no mediar palabra, y los flashbacks que se generan en ocasiones son MUY bonitos. Me parece que el juego consigue mucho con lo poco que tiene.

En definitiva, una aventura gráfica suave, que puede meter a un nuevo jugador a este género sin problemas.

I remembered playing this game years ago and finding it cool. Finally, after years of wait I found it again and beat it to say that it was much better than I expected. So, let me share some things that matter before buying the game:

[list]
    [*]Is the story well written?
    [*]How do different kind of players do with such a game and how hard is it to catch on regarding on your gaming experience?
    [*]Is the game completionist friendly?
[/list]

[b]I found the story to be cute and well told through the ways this game expresses it. [/b][spoiler]While it is somewhat predictable, it feels satisfying to complete it since it feels like you earn everything you get[/spoiler] 

It doesn't matter what skill level you are - [b]you will struggle either way. [/b] It is no Pokémon shield, by which I mean that you aren't spoon fed the story and the solutions - quite the opposite - you have to fight for every single bite since this game is what seems to have been a medieval torture device accidentally made into a game. Your brain will be fried and you will regret every second if you attempt beating this game in one sitting. [spoiler] Also the 'A.I.' is quite simply cheating  in some parts so best of luck. [/spoiler]

Completionists will be happy to hear that this game reaches 100% completion as soon as you finish the story, therefore[b] it is very completionist friendly.[/b] On the other hand, completing the game itself is not easy without using external help.

This game is worth the money, especially if it happens to be on sale. Good puzzle games don't appear often these days so I suggest trying such gems when you have the time.

111225431.review:
I feel so wrong giving Machinarium a negative review. It does so many things exceptionally well, but is held back from being a game I can truly recommend by some horrible, glaring flaws. Flaws so catastrophic that it drags an otherwise excellent package to a frustrating mess.

-I had 2 big, gamebreaking bugs in my playthrough. This is a 5-8 hr long game. There are like 30 screens total. For 2 of them to be impassable is just unacceptable. The first was the elevator bug (documented here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/40700/discussions/0/1473096694444777484/), which required me to change the size of my window in game from fullscreen to 90% windowed to solve. Now, keep in mind, this is the type of bug where I don't KNOW if it's bugged or if I'm just doing the puzzle wrong, so naturally I wasted an hour or more of my life sitting there thinking it was me and not the game, before I eventually looked it up and found out the game was at fault. Stellar. The second gamebreaking bug I was able to diagnose rather quickly, but basically there's a puzzle which I couldn't get to work properly on mouse + keyboard (this is a point and click adventure game...) but for whatever reason my gamepad worked just fine

-So that's bad enough, but truth be told the game is plagued by control problems throughout. The zones they gave for "clickable" parts of the background are either too large or too small. So very often a puzzle wasn't challenging because I couldn't figure it out, but because I didn't know I could click there, or even worse, because I already tried to click there but nothing happened because I didn't click in the exact right zone. The large ranges are particularly annoying when it moves your robot to places you don't want it to ... overall the whole thing just feels clunky.

-Part of this is that Machinarium does something unique that I thought I'd like, but ended up despising. Basically for a thing to be clickable / interactable, your robot has to be right next to it. And your robot has 3 sizes (tall, normal, and small). This is different from traditional point-and-click adventure games in that generally the whole screen is clickable in this genre. What this ends up meaning is you move your robot to every node that he can move to, make him change sizes every time you do, and see if anything is clickable. You do this on every screen to see what you can interact with. This is not fun. And keep in mind all of the robot's animations are painfully slow. Joy.

-But really, at the crux of it all is that though I did 2/3rds of the puzzles in the game unaided, there was a third of them that were just painful. And if you know this genre, you know that being stuck in a point-and-click adventure game with no idea what to do is a special sort of pain that just drains your life away. To the game's credit, there is a hint and walkthrough system implemented, but like most, I -really- didn't want to use them. I eventually caved, and that feeling has stuck with me since. If you're the type of gamer who can feel good even when using a guide, or hints, or a walkthrough, then maybe it won't bother you. But otherwise you'll likely be facing the doomed choice of whether to cheat or to suffer in point and click hell with no clue what to do. And for me, the controls were too cumbersome for me to persevere. I just got tired.

-The coup de grâce was the final puzzle, which requires you to play back some musical notes you hear. This is bad enough because not only do I have no musical talent, but I'm actually hard of hearing in one of my ears (how's that for accessibility). But OK fine, maybe I could have done it anyway, but unbelievably, there is BACKGROUND MUSIC playing while you are supposed to be honing in on this musical sound effect that you'll have to memorize and play back. And the background music is the most horrific, unbearable track in the game! So I'm sitting there, trying to stir up the little musical acumen I have to memorize this melody while suffering through this distracting noise in the background and I broke. I used the walkthrough feature for the first time because to hell with it I just wanted it to be over. And so ended Machinarium for me. Not with a bang, but a whimper.

So yeah, I WANT to like Machinarium. I like point and click adventure games. The game is cute as hell. The artstyle is gorgeous. The music (other than that one track) is great! The worldbuilding and way it communicates story beats is awesome. And actually, the 2/3rds of the puzzles which clicked for me were pretty enjoyable. There is so much to like! But in the end, this is what my experience was, and I can't lie to you all. My playthrough was buggy, frustrating, and most importantly, fruitless. Sad.

[h1]Puzzle[/h1]

As a fan of old-school point and click games, I really wanted to love Machinarium. It has lots of things going for it: a wonderful aesthetic, endearing characters, and good music. But for me, the majority of the gameplay falls flat.

110290867.review:
I both like and dislike this game. 

Story is extremely simple in the way it is conveyed, but damn the puzzle elements in this game can be brutal.

The fact that the game has its own built in walkthrough tells me already that I should expect to get stuck at certain points, and at many I did. To my disappointment, just to access said walkthrough requires its own minigame which runs on far longer than it needs to, and you need to do this EVERY time you want to glance the vague pages contained within. It's not necessarily because the puzzles were too hard (Some absolutely were) that I got stuck, but more-so because the game blends everything together so well that it's hard to differentiate objects and interactables at times, which results in a hodge-podge clickfest where you spam the entire screen seeing if anything will react. 

A good deal of the puzzles have the ability to reset in case you back yourself into a corner, others, aren't so forgiving. The bead/abacus styled puzzle infuriated me for this. My initial train of thought led me to a tedious manual rewind to revert puzzle to its base state. Some of the puzzles I genuinely enjoyed, like the Greenhouse switchboard, others I hated. 

The game features a unique mechanic wherein you can only interact with objects that are within arms reach. Whilst this initially comes across as cool this soon overstays its welcome. By the end of the game I was bored and sick to death of having to manually move the robot beside objects I wished to grab, pull, push, twist or turn. I was even further enraged at the absolute piss poor performance of the game in general. It was as if the game was having frequent lag spikes, but not lag per se', but rather, the game slowed, and then sped up again, this occurred quite legitimately every 2 seconds. This impacted absolutely everything in the game, from menu's, to puzzles, to movement, to scripted sequences. 

All in all I enjoyed the game on a surface level, but I have definitively no intentions to ever revisit the game. It has its charm, but the brutal nature of the puzzles being mostly guesswork, even down to their location at times, just kinda of dragged the game down to a slog for me. Whilst I actually quite enjoyed a few puzzles, most just felt they got more obscure the further into the game I progressed. I honestly felt the games strongest point was its opening, all the way until you hit the band, then it got harder, quite faster.

Pro's:
- Cute artstyle that stands out amongst the crowd. 
- Diverse soundtrack to fit a multitude of scenarios and backdrops in this quirky little robot world.
- Some at times, very clever puzzles that are borderline hard, but easy enough to nail down with a bit of thinking. 
- Extremely easy and simple narrative to follow. Save robot girlfriend; escape. 
- Good sound design that adequately portrays the motions on screen. 

Cons:
- Non-conclusive tutorial. Shows you how to grow taller to reach objects, doesn't explain that you can shrink, and you will need to for some puzzles.
- Some completely mind-wracking puzzles.
- Tedious, drawn out animations and sequences that you will have to repeat time after time. 
- Completely appalling performance.


Verdict: Buy on steep sale. Honestly, at $22 AUD, I cannot recommend this game. The price hardly reflects the content of the game. I have 6 hours recorded and that was even including times I got majorly stuck. I have paid far less for far more.

Neither here nor there. I don't believe this game deserves the appraisal that it's the best point+click ever, but I'd hardly say it was a bad experience. 

6.5/10.

110202140.review:
[h1]One of the few times that the digital collector's edition is worth it[/h1]
I played this game for the first time when I was 15 years old, way back when it was released in 2009. To this day, I'm not sure where exactly I heard about it, but its distinct art direction immediately caught my eye.

In [i]Machinarium[/i] you play as a little robot dude (whose name is, in fact, Josef - something I wasn't aware of until I started writing this review) searching a vast, industrial citadel for his kidnapped girlfriend. Pretty standard protagonist motivation, but the game isn't particularly narrative heavy. Beyond an occasional speech bubble pictogram, the story takes somewhat of a backseat to the gameplay. You're definitely heading [i]somewhere[/i] throughout the game, but the puzzles and setting tend to much more predominantly occupy the mind.

The puzzles themselves are pretty satisfying to figure out. When I played Machinarium back in 2009, I quickly became overwhelmed once the world opened up and the puzzles began to span over several screens. Coming back to it with more experience in the point-and-click genre, it was certainly tricky in places, but no puzzle was frustratingly convoluted. There's even a built-in minigame that allows you to play a retro-styled side scrolling shoot-em-up, the beating of which earns you a hint for the current screen you're on.

Machinarium's world feels alive, which is ironic since the setting is largely a barren metal metropolis. Some puzzles require interacting with the various characters that populate the world, and others require keenly observing what's in front of you. The character designs are simplistic, but iconic, and it's easy to get behind the plight of our cute robot protagonist.

One last thing. This game's soundtrack is [b]PERFECTION[/b].

If for some reason you aren't interested in the same itself, I'd go so far as to recommend simply purchasing the standalone Soundtrack + Art book when its on sale. The soundtrack is pure ear candy. It blends the organic and the synthentic, with tremendously crisp production. Whether you're bopping your head or soaking in the gleaming crystalline ambience, each track keeps your ear guessing what unique sound is going to present itself next. Acoustic recordings and electronic elements blend seamlessly, and everything sits just in the right place in the mix. Tomáš Dvořák (the composer) is clearly a very talented dude, and his work here only elevates an already excellent game to masterpiece status.

9.5/10

Mechinarium is a artistic puzzle game that is both kid friendly and adult relaxing gaming. The puzzles are enjoyable and with a wide variety of styles. The story is perfect for a younger age. The graphics are cute and nicely done. The dialogue boxes are also a nice touch, and would also be perfect for a youngster playing.

The music is very mellow. Even the more uptempo music is relaxing. This fits well with the art and game style. The progression is fun, and allows for a more open feel than many puzzle games that I have played in the past.  

While this is a kid friendly game, some of the puzzles might require some parent assistance. This would be a great father and/or mother with son and/or daughter game. This is a great short game for a family activity. There are many different mini games with many different flavors of style, as well as a touch of nostalgia for those around my age. 

In all, this game is recommended, but I would consider it more orientated for the young, and plan on gifting this to my niece for her kiddos. Cheers and Game On!

My only real negatives in the game are that it's very light on story, and that it is a pixel hunting nightmare. There is no button that highlights the interactable points on screen and the mouse won't show them either unless your character is physically next to it. Combine this with the fact that the game also refuses to allow you to use items with an interactable object unless you're right next to it, and this can quickly lead to being stuck through no fault of your own - I was stymied for half an hour because of this as I used the right object at the correct location, but the game decided my character wasn't close enough and refused the interaction, leading me to believe that it was wrong and to search for another solution. Really irritating. Still well worth playing for the puzzles and gorgeous visuals - just don't feel bad if you need to refer to a guide once or twice because of the lack of player friendly mechanics.

106964123.review:
A little robot reactivates itself in a scrapyard and proceeds to find and rescue his metallic girlfriend from a bunch of robotic hooligans. Relying on visual storytelling and forgoing elaborate dialogue and text boxes, Machinarium's plot is simple and straightforward, but sweet and endearing. Given the fact that no refined concepts and ideas are proposed by the game, its primary strength is the cartoonesque presentation of a surrealistic and decayed world populated by different models of robots. As the player progresses in the story, the lives and conditions of these robotic beings are alluded by the short interactions between them and the protagonist. This minimalistic narrative creates a world that, despite its whimsical characters and aesthetic, feels common, familiar and human.

Gameplay revolves around the use of the mouse. All actions are performed by clicking somewhere on the screen, whether to move the playable character, employ an inventory item or manipulate something in the area. It's a modest system that works pretty well most of the time, although the inventory bag may be a bit cumbersome to handle. Moving the robot is also slightly restricted, as it is only allowed to walk to and stay on specific spots in any given screen.

Being a point n' click game, Machinarium challenges the player with a plethora of puzzles that differ in terms of difficulty and design. Most of these obstacles are intuitive and easy to solve, but others may require a bit of thinking in order to be understood. A hint book with the solutions to these puzzles is available to the player, and each explanation is locked behind a simple minigame -- a necessary penalty to be paid, in case one becomes stuck in a particular conundrum. At first, puzzles are self-contained in their respective screens, but they do spread out later on as the game opens up and the player is given freedom to tackle problems in multiple areas.

In a few words, Machinarium is a short experience that does not overstay its welcome and should amuse players who enjoy a lighthearted story with a sizeable dose of clever problem-solving.

106531505.review:
Pros:
+ Excellent animation, beautiful hand-drawn art.
+ Nice soundtrack.
+ Original and intriguing background setting with interesting plot.
+ Has a great variety of puzzles. Some (but very few) are purely logic/deduction-based and are satisfying to solve.
+ No missable achievement. In fact, you will have unlocked all achievements when you complete the game.

Cons:
- Awkward control and interaction.
- Slow walking speed of the protagonist. This is exacerbated by the intentional design that you can only know whether an object is interactable when you are near it.
- Tedious and dragging mini-games, which are compulsory to advance the plot or unlock walkthrough book.
- Only provides one hint per scene. If you need more, the only option is to consult the in-game walkthrough book. However, this book is unlocked on a per-scene basis and requires playing a mini-game.
- Most puzzles are moon logic kind. Really difficult to proceed without any hints, which are difficult to obtain due to the previous point.

Despite its strength in animation and music, I cannot recommend this game since its puzzle design is atrocious. This opinion is shared by many other negative reviews on Steam, which you are more than recommended to read if you are still on the fence. My suggestion is that unless you are really into its art style, avoid it like a plague, especially if you are a puzzle lover.

106440993.review:
One of Amanita Design's first games, Machinarium, is one of my favorite point-and-click adventures. It's got everything I love in their games; whimsical worlds and environments, an uneasy, nostalgic, and melancholic soundtrack, and sound direction that eases player input with visual response. 

Most definitely one of Amanita's harder games with its puzzles, but one of their most rewarding; the game offers hints of different variation if need be. 

Machinarium is charmingly simple with its mechanics, but are applied in creative ways. I really do feel as if I am a tin robot in a mechanical-ridden planet, on a quest to punish the evildoers, deactivate a bomb, and find my robot girlfriend.

Machinarium is a small point and click puzzle game, with weird graphics and a cute little robot as the main protagonist.

Don't get afraid of the somewhat old and strange looking design of the game. I'm sure you will love it real fast. In the pure tradition of point and clicks, you progress in a succession of puzzle scenes. The puzzles are challenging, without being too difficult in my opinion.

The strength of the game is the strange robot world where the adventure takes place. It is hard to describe, but its worth the discovery. The humor is omnipresent, mostly in the form of weird (and sometimes very dumb) robot characters, but also in the way you will solve some of the puzzles.

Machinarium is a game that may not look like much, but is an actual must do. Special mention to the soundtrack by Tomas Dvorak, which I love. In the same vein as the game, it is short, weird, but so relaxing and soothing.
