105673042.review:
I replayed this game for the first time in about a decade, and I have to say, it's every bit as good now as it was back then. This is a wonderful point-and-click adventure game which is very unique in almost every way; the art style is loose and soulful, detailed but leaves much to the imagination. The music is deep and atmospheric, and doesn't become irritating or repetitive during the long moments you'll spend in certain areas. The characters and animations are charming and somehow even the villains are endearing. The puzzles are range from very simple to rather difficult but I don't find myself struggling much. Some of the puzzles are so brilliant that they could be extended into entire games themselves. It's short and sweet, and the world isn't really large enough to make backtracking a tedious chore.

You feel like a foreigner trying to understand a new culture.

I really can't praise this game enough. I'm not really one to play point-and-clicks, but this remains one of my favorite games and one of my favorite game-worlds. There's something for everyone here and I can't recommend it enough.

This is a very rare 10/10

105381188.review:
[h1] Incredibly beautiful point & click adventure game [/h1]

This is an old game but can still be played without any issues today (and maybe in 20 years) thanks to its amazing graphics.
Most of the scenes are pure art and the hand drawing style will never get old.
It's oozing with cuteness and small details which makes it very pleasing to the eyes.

Some moments are just too much and it's incredible how they made all the animations so perfect and smooth. Just seeing the little guy dance during one of the puzzles is just pure delight and much cuter than watching videos of puppies.

The music is also really good, it sets the mood nicely in each screens and some tunes in specific parts of the game will stick in your head being so catchy!

Without giving away too many spoilers, let's stay the story is quite basic. Even without dialogues, it has its own charm and the characters are all wonderfully designed that you will love each of them. There is an underlying sense of humor in most small cut scenes which helps attach you to them.
 
The one important thing to note is that this game is [b]VERY HARD![/b]
Some puzzles are obscure, the in game hint system can help you a little bit but sometimes you might still end up stuck. A big difference with other classic point & click games is that this one will only tell you if an item combination or action works if in the zone of interaction of your little guy, meaning you can click on an item and select a panel across the screen where you guy is, you have to move him next to it, so it might take more time to find what's interactive or not.
There are also various mini games but nothing too demanding action wise, some are simple puzzles while others are really more like small Atari games.

I highly recommend this game since unlike some other point & click classics, it didn't age at all and is a very beautiful and challenging game. You might want to wait a sale to get it cheaper since it can be beaten rushed in less than 3 hours but it will be a very nice 3 hours (unless you drive yourself crazy with the puzzles!).

104920982.review:
Machinarium, del 16 de Octubre del 2009, es una aventura gráfica tipo Point and Click. 
Somos un pequeño robot llamado Josef, descartado en un vertedero, que debemos (a través de la resolución de Puzzles), primero rescatar nuestras piezas faltantes, y luego, salvar al jefe de la ciudad, derrotar a la malvada Hermandad del Gorro Negro y rescatar a nuestra novia Berta. La ambientación es artística, y representa una ciudad industrial llena de robots y estructuras mecánicas.
El juego no contiene diálogos escritos entre los personajes, usando un sistema de globos de diálogo animados para la comunicación entre los personajes.
Existe un mecanismo de pistas, de manera que  podemos recibir solo una por cada nivel, que nos indique qué tenemos que hacer para progresar en el juego. Sin embargo, cuanto más se avanza en el juego, las pistas se vuelven más complicadas. Además, el juego incluye una guía al que se puede acceder siempre, jugando un minijuego. La guía, como todo lo demás, no está escrita, sino que está compuesta de una serie de dibujos en forma de historieta.

104868203.review: Machinarium has been on my top 3 games since 2009. The puzzles, the style, the soundtrack. It stands the test of time, and honestly everything amanita design does is just magnificent. It's done with so much attention to detail, and the pacing of the game is just right for me.

Ok, first of all, Machinarium as a game alone is perfect for me. It's a point and click puzzle game with an amazing artstyle and very unique setting.
That being said, this game is NOT easy. It is short, but under no circumstances is it easy to complete without a guide. Every puzzle is very unique and difficult to understand and get the hang of, and one of them is even up to rng.

This game gives off a very eerie vibe while playing. The lack of music most of the time, the sound effects, the artstyle and setting. Even some of the puzzles themselves are pretty creepy in design. But if you're into stuff like that (as am I) then this game is for you.

Now I did say this game is short and it doesn't have many achievements, but you get all of them for just completing the game normally, so if you want to buy it for the achievements then go for it.
I still say go for it anyway, because I think this game is a masterpiece

A typical problem of the AVG games is that there is typically only one solution to proceed with the game.  So if the players cannot think in a similar way that developers do, the game will be stuck somewhere in the game inevitably.  

Machinarium resolved this problem in a very smart way.  There is this in-game book provides a lot of additional leads and ideas which should help most players get through.  The only thing the player needs to do is to play a mini game before every time you open the help book.  Therefore the player can choose how much additional help you want to use.

I didn't like it.

The presentation is beautiful, the music and art are fantastic and captivating. But the puzzles after a while turned into an exercise in patience.

They often require you to be extremely specific in the way they're solved, sometimes you might think you need to pick up something only to then try to do so and not be able to, subsequently finding out, hours later, that you WERE supposed to pick up said item, only to find out you had to be crouched down in order to do so.

You play as a robot, and it controls like it...

You're slow and the game is designed in such a way that at later levels you need to backtrack to other locations turning the simple act of traversing from point a to point b into a chore.

In other cases, the hints present solutions that aren’t possible if you follow a particular route that deviates from the developer’s original rationale.

Near the end you must play this sort of tic tac toe game in a huge board with another robot, it took me a bunch of tries and after every single loss my opponent would laugh, all of this accompanied by the background smooth jazz music of the bar I was in.

It was unbearable.

98228257.review:
[h1][b]ANÁLISIS DE [i]MACHINARIUM [/i]:[/b][/H1]

[i]Machinarium[/i] es una aventura gráfica tipo point & click del año 2009 que todo fan de este género debería jugar. A continuación os cuento los motivos:

[h1]Argumento:[/h1] (no incluye spoilers)

Controlamos a Josef, un pequeño robot que se ve envuelto en un lío por error, teniendo como objetivo rescatar a su novia Berta, que ha sido secuestrada por la Hermandad del Sombrero Negro.

Con este típico y simple argumento, que deducimos tras leer la ficha del juego y tras ir avanzando en los primeros compases de la aventura, nos damos cuenta de que la profundidad del mismo es algo secundario en este juego. De hecho, no se dice ni una sola palabra durante toda la aventura, todo se deduce a partir de gestos, "bocadillos" tipo cómic con garabatos trazados a mano de una forma simple pero que acompañados de las animaciones y gestos dotan de una expresividad maravillosa al juego.

[h1]Jugabilidad:[/h1]

Se puede usar mando, pero lógicamente para este tipo de juegos se recomienda mucho más el uso del ratón. Como en todos los point & click el control es simple, pon el cursor del ratón sobre la zona/objeto con el que quieres interactuar y listo. En Machinarium el cursor cambia a la forma de la mano de Josef para poder interactuar, donde no se pueda simplemente no cambiará. Es simple pero efectivo, aunque también he de reconocer que a veces no responde del todo bien si lo comparamos con otras grandes aventuras gráficas similares, a la hora de marcar lo que queremos hacer podría haber estado más pulido y ser más fino, también a la hora de deshacer una acción.

[h1]Gráficos:[/h1]

Uno de los apartados más destacables de Machinarium. No son unos gráficos que destaquen por su gran calidad ni por su realismo como ya habréis podido apreciar con solo ver la portada del juego o las imágenes, pero el mimo con el que están dibujados a mano todos los diseños de los personajes y escenarios es impresionante, que acompañado de unas simpáticas animaciones dotan al juego de un aspecto único y genial.

[h1]Sonido:[/h1]

Otro apartado genial de Machinarium. La banda sonora es sobresaliente (podéis escucharla en Spotify [url=https://open.spotify.com/album/52PLNrXUMtPUZwcueV75J1?si=5NoMnLQeTdOZw2z3bkNsOw&dl_branch=1]AQUÍ[/url]), añadiendo el sonido ambiental y los que reproducen los personajes, que como os dije antes no hablan pero entre sus gestos, ruidos y lo que muestran sus pensamientos por medio de los "bocadillos" nos harán saber en todo momento qué quieren expresarnos.

Sin más, os dejo mi lista de pros y contras:

[H1][b]PROS:[/b][/H1]

- La estética es simplemente genial, los diseños dibujados a mano le dan un aspecto único

- La banda sonora es sobresaliente  (podéis escucharla en Spotify [url=https://open.spotify.com/album/52PLNrXUMtPUZwcueV75J1?si=5NoMnLQeTdOZw2z3bkNsOw&dl_branch=1]AQUÍ[/url])

- La gran variedad de puzles

- Los escenarios

- El carisma de los personajes a pesar de no decir ni una sola palabra en todo el juego

- Está traducido al español

- El original sistema de pistas

- Tiene logros Steam

- Tiene cromos y artículos en la tienda de puntos de Steam

- Se puede encontrar a buen precio en épocas de ofertas

[H1][b]CONTRAS:[/b][/H1]

- Se hace corto, aunque todo depende de la destreza que tengas para solucionar los diferentes puzles

- La dificultad de algunos de sus rompecabezas puede echar atrás a algunos jugadores

- Los logros solo son por avanzar en la historia, hubiese estado bien añadir alguno “perdible”

- El control no responde todo lo bien que debería en algunas ocasiones

- Algo inestable, he sufrido alguna que otra salida al escritorio en una zona concreta (la escena de la cárcel debajo de la mesa)

[H1]Conclusión:[/h1]

Una pequeña joya, ya solo por la forma en la que está contada la historia, el mimo de su apartado visual y su banda sonora, resulta un título imprescindible si te gustan las aventuras gráficas estilo “point & click".

Si mi análisis te ha gustado o te ha servido de ayuda, agradecería que dejaras un voto positivo para que pueda llegar a más gente. También se agradecen los premios. ¡Gracias por leerme! No dudéis en dejar vuestros comentarios o dudas, responderé lo antes posible.

Machinarium is one of the best games of all time, without a doubt. It simply is pure joy to experience. It is like few other games in its ability to create a world with so little. The Czech game scene is driven by few, but it is definitively driven by Amanita Design. This game, and all their games, is a powerful representation of the Czech Republics ability to create strong, penetrative content. BUY THIS GAME! It is like few other things on the market, and will beguile and intrigue you. 

In many ways, this game is like playing an instrument. It deserves your attention, and the payoff is incredibly satisfying. 

Play this game, I implore you. If you love art. If you love narrative. If you love games! Play this one! It's one for the history books without a doubt.

The game play of this point'n click is fair and simple and never distract you from the story and its trashy and beautiful atmosphere. The music is super cool, kudos to the three robot musicians who play a terrific jazzy sound! I love it. There are also some references to the 1980's games in this game. I give it plenty of stars and clearly recommend it!

95337632.review:
[b] Point&click Adventure game with challenging puzzles, great story telling and particular graphic designs. 7/10 [/b]

I was drawn to this game by its reviews and I admit that I completely agree with what people say about this game. I appreciated that you can complete every achievement just by finishing the main story line. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
Even though some puzzles might be quite challenging, it is pretty clear what the goal is. Except for one case, where it was not clear at all and I just had to take a guess. Although it is quite common to have hints in this kind of games, it's the first time that I see the game itself providing the whole walkthrough for a certain area directly in the game. What I mean is that, if you are stuck in this game, you can simply play a minigame to access the whole solution. I have used once but I felt it was too much detailed and complete, giving me way more information than I needed. I liked a lot that items get thrown away after being used, so, you do not keep your inventory full with stuff that you won't probably need anymore.

I had the feeling from the start that I would see and know more about the surrounding world but the game does not explore what is around the initial city, nor it gives any explanation on why there is a town of robots and why some of them grow plants. But it's just like that. Moreover, there are so many puzzle that I think the point&click game has been built around a puzzle game.

Concerning its duration, I have finished it in 7 hours and personally I feel it was a bit "too short" compared to other Point&Click games, but it is just my opinion. 

[h1] Graphics [/h1]
I have really appreciated the decision to avoid any kind of written dialogue by focusing on visual communication. The graphic design is quite particular, someone might like it or not. However, you can immediately see from the start the attention to details and animations. This game is full of puzzle, and details help you a lot understand what to do.

Totally recommended!

94266899.review:
[b][i]An Adorable But Difficult Puzzle Game: 7/10[/i][/b]
---------------------
[u]For Linux Gamers:[/u] Runs without issue with Proton 6
--------------------
I can understand why Machinarium reached cult status in these 10 years. Gorgeous pencil art with hypnotic Radiohead-esque soundtrack really will draw a lot of your attention. The almost movie-like story-telling is also enamoring. However, below the surface lies a difficult game, one that is not suited for mere casuals. If you’re willing to persevere headache-inducing puzzles, the story-telling, art and music can be rewarding. 
--------------------
[b]What’s Excellent[/b]
--------------------
The hand-drawn pencil art graphics, character designs and world-building are [u]top-tier movie quality animation.[/u] Machinarium is a looker and coupled with a [u]high-class experimental electronica[/u] gives bleak but hopeful atmosphere. Never have escaping from dystopia been so cute. 

Even though the plot is very generic, the [u]clever story-telling[/u] deserves praise as well. There are no dialogue in Machinarium; all the narrative is done visually and it the delivery is splendid. 
--------------------
[b]What’s Bad[/b]
--------------------
[u]Controls are not good[/u] to be honest. For a Point & Click game, the pointing and clicking sure feels clunky. Moving from point A to point B is simply guesswork and once you initiate movement, sometimes you can’t cancel or stop. 

The [u]user interface is also pretty bad.[/u] Your inventory is just a top panel and is tedious to access, while your taskbar sometimes gets in your way when you’re trying to do complex puzzles. 
--------------------
[b]What’s In The Middle[/b]
--------------------
The gameplay is decent. The puzzles are great but there are varying degrees of difficulty ranging from easy to extremely hard. I’m talking about abstract thinking and mathematical thought processes near esoteric level. If you are an average person, these puzzles are daunting. There is a manual that can help you as well as a hint button. But to access the manual - which only tells you how to solve [i]some[/i] puzzles - you will need to play a short shoot-em-up game. And the harder puzzles such as the Prison Lock puzzle, The 3 Wrenches puzzle, or the Bead Puzzle are not given solutions, rather you’re suppose to figure it all out yourself. 
--------------------
[b]Conclusion[/b]
--------------------
This is going to be a soft recommendation from me. If you like puzzles, Machinarium will provide challenge. If you’re not an experienced puzzle player, this ain’t it.

Como el resto de juegos de Amanita Design, Machinarium es un juego de gran belleza estética, inmersivo y cautivador por su música envolvente y su calidad gráfica. Uno puede deleitarse contemplando cada escenario. Buen juego para capturas de pantalla. 
Según progresamos vamos conociendo la historia del pequeño robot mediante algunos ágiles y esquemáticos flashbacks que nos muestran las desventuras del tragicómico protagonista destartalado. 
Como aventura gráfica que es, su historia, aunque sencilla y fácil de seguir, es simpática y conmovedora a la vez.  La ventaja es que no es necesario leer ni escuchar largos discursos, todo se entiende de forma sencilla con unas pocas imágenes que lo aclaran y explican todo lo necesario. 
Juego de point-and-click, resolver situaciones, problemas, minijuegos, puzzles, buscar objetos, salidas secretas, abrir puertas cerradas, explorar el entorno, encontrar y accionar palancas, apretar botones en orden, compuertas escondidas, códigos secretos, entender combinaciones, coordinar mecanismos y acciones, etc. No apto para personas que no le guste demasiado darle vueltas a los problemas o tengan poca paciencia, tampoco para aquellos que busquen acción y velocidad trepidante. Se trata de un juego más bien contemplativo, de prestar atención al entorno, pensar un rato y complacerse con los espectaculares escenarios pintados a mano. Es mejor jugar con calma, detenimiento y disfrutar, ya que no es un juego demasiado rejugable.

92596262.review:
Machinarium is obviously no where near one of my most played games hours wise, yet it lives in my head in a way most games that I've played for hundreds of hours fail to. I didn't really know much about this game before I played it but I became intrigued by the soundtrack, which is made by Floex(Tomas Dvorak) and then promptly fully convinced by what I saw when I looked it up on steam. And man am I glad I played this little gem.

From the first time I got into it I was fully absorbed into the rich, beautiful atmosphere and the cute robotic characters that lived in it, as well as the chilled out but engaging point and click game play mechanics. Tomas absolutely does not disappoint with the soundtrack (my favorite track is 'By the Wall'), which stays true to his pretty, often jazzy, ambient electronic style and perfectly backdrops the gorgeous hand made environments that Machinarium offers throughout every level of the game. Most of the experience is spent in a melancholic cityscape brought to life by impossibly charismatic robots, an adorable childlike main character and convincing intractable set pieces, which are used to solve the puzzles and navigate through the city. Nearly every part of this game seems to have an over the top, blunt way of expressing itself to you in place of conventional dialogue and storytelling, making just existing within the game whilst you play it an absolute joy. 

The cute main robot and point and click puzzle game play of Machinarium actually serve to pull you even deeper into it's world by forcing you to think about the oppressing, intense city with a naive, childlike curiosity. I only spent 15 hours on it but in retrospect it feels like much longer. The puzzles are fairly challenging and have a brilliant way of feeling rewarding without being too obvious or too obscure. I personally found the arcade game you have to play to unlock hints a bit grading at first, however, that actually inspired me to try and use it more sparingly. By referencing previous levels and scrutinizing my entire computer screen, I could usually lead myself to that glorious "aha" moment. When I did need help, the hints are always just vague enough to lead you down the right path without losing the fun value.

All in all, Machinarium is a textbook example of the power in simplicity, quality over quantity and a rare, special game that I think almost anyone could enjoy.

An outstanding point and click adventure puzzle game, Amanita design are a master in their field, and the stunning scenes they create are truly wonderful to navigate, the city of Machinarium truly feels like a living city,  and your journey through it's crumbling and rusted streets and plazas make you wonder as to the backstory of the setting, something that is never really explained, it is plain however that Machinarium is only a shadow of it's former self, and you get the feeling the city is, if not dying, certainly falling into a deeper disrepair.

The puzzles are challenging and interesting, and if you get stuck don't feel like you shouldn't use the help book, because you actually have to work for your help in this game by... completing a small minigame, this is a masterful way of making the tip book not feel like cheating, along with the fact the book is written in the same odd language the robots use, I love this, as it means that the book is a physical item the main character owns, not just an intangible cheat guide, and therefore there's nothing to make you feel bad about using it if you get stuck, I know I certainly did a few times.

I you want a challenging game with stunning art direction and a charming story, Machinarium is the game for you, and so is Samarost, Amanita's other flagship work, and one you should check out too.

91784910.review:
I purchased Machinarium in a Humble Bundle sometime in 2014. It sat on my backlog for an inexcusable 7 years! I am writing this review to publicly admit to and atone for this mistake. Machinarium is a really good game! You should play it.

Everything about this game is charming. The art is wonderful. In an age where most indie games have amazing art, it really manages to stand out with it's grungy picture book aesthetic. There is an obvious amount of care and detail placed into the animation and the character design. 

The score contains everything from blissed out ambient vibes to funky robot party music. Every song has a wistful, slightly broken sound and every sound effect is perfectly chosen to compliment the score. Every screen is just bursting with personality and life.

The puzzles are fun, maybe a little easy, but the joy never really came for me from being stumped by an obtuse solution. It was more fun to see something and know that it would be used in a puzzle somehow and remembering to come back to it at the right point. Almost like a Metroidvania, I really enjoyed opening up new areas or interactions that were initially just out of reach.

The story is an absolute masterclass in telling a simple narrative effectively. There's no dialogue, just a bunch of goofy robots and the occasional thought bubble. You are given the information you need as you go and the game just lets the world speak for itself. A lot of games try to do this now, so many fail, but it's one of Machinarium's biggest strengths.

If you have this game sitting in your library, just knock it out. I got so invested that the 5 hour play time just flew by. If you don't have it already, it's old enough now that you can almost certainly pick it up for pocket change, but even at full price it's worth every penny.

I'd say the best selling point to this game is the hand drawn graphics. It's able to make a dystopian city that looks a bit run down come to life with the sheer detail that's put into the world and humorous character designs. Gameplay wise it's a decent point and click that I'd recommend for beginners due to the mostly basic puzzles and short game length, however there's not much more upside to that. 

A few issues I have is that some of the puzzles aren't exactly intuitive but basic enough to be solved with a little bit of trial and error which I didn't find all that satisfying. The other issue I had involved a puzzle that required to be able to differentiate music notes which isn't really a skill I have and so I had to use the solution book in order to progress that. Lastly there is a puzzle in the game that was broken for me until I discovered I had to change my window resolution in order for the controls to work which was a bit annoying.

As for the price point I wouldn't buy this game unless it were on sale as I feel $22 AUD is a premium price for a game that doesn't really offer more than a few hours of playtime, but nonetheless if you're a beginner wanting to explore the point and click genre I'd say this is a good entry game at best.

89749169.review:
I will preface this review by saying that this is my first time playing a point&click puzzle game. With that said, I really liked it. I was originally drawn toward this game for its art and and that is probably the strongest part of the game and what you should be playing it for (You see the trailer, the whole game is consistently just that good).

I heard some point&click are very story-driven. Not this one though, its story is as simple as stop the bad guys and save your girlfriend. 

As for the item / logic puzzles, I enjoyed most of them, but to my limited knowledge, there isn't anything groundbreaking there. There is nothing I'd really call moon logic, and there was only two times ever I gave up and used the guide. I did really like how player-friendly the game is. I don't think there is anyway to softlock yourself, and any item you no longer need for latter puzzles are always taken away. 

Something I really liked was the hint system. In each screen, you get a hint, which usually point you to what you should work toward doing for that puzzle, without telling you the answer. Thanks to this system, there is rarely a point in a game in which I have no idea what I should do, without having to look up a walkthrough and potentially get spoiled.

The only problem I have is that sometimes I don't actually know what I'm solving a puzzle for. I mean, it usually always give you an item that let you solve some other puzzle, it's just not always clear what that item is. This could just be because my lack of experience with the genre though.

[h1]

If you like the point & click genre, you should really try it out.We play a robot trying to save his lover in a dystopian robot world with beautiful puzzles and a very pretty sweet design style.The game's unique world, pastel color palette, drawings / designs and pretty good music make the game great. On the other hand, it seems like every frame is made for watching, every sound and music you can hear. The story is fluid and intriguing, and the puzzle parts are sufficiently challenging. [h1]

Pros:
+the graphics are pretty sweet

Machinarium is one of those games I played first time in my early 20's but remember as a part of my childhood. Artistically it levels with so many childlike planes of perspective, there's something very innocent and pure about the whole experience. Even after a decade it feels like fresh breath of air for a point n' click story, partly from the space it leaves your interpretation with a zero-dialogue-basis, but also from just being one of those timeless creations resembling a living piece of art. It's full of clever puzzles backed with good music and wonky characters, a very calming and unique experience that works for both the oldest and youngest generations.

It's difficult to find anything negative to say about this game. I hope to see more titles like it, and it's a genre I'll keep coming back to in 25 years, as much as I do now and 25 years ago.

Atmosphere, music and humour. These are all on point in this gem of a game which, I think, is now considered classic.

Who says you need a story? It's a basic damsel-in-distress situation where you are the hero who saves the day. That being said, there are a lot of small stories in there, if you pay attention to the characters you encounter along the way.

And who says you need actual dialogue? Everything is explained visually to great effect but some of the puzzles will try your brain, nevertheless. Well, they did mine, which might not be saying much, but still.

84932736.review:
Loved it. Wish it wasn't so short and that a sequel was made. I'm going to guess 5-8 hour length for most people, and a good chunk of that will be on a few of the tougher puzzles unless you look up solutions. It's probably worth full price if you can enjoy good art. If you just want to speedrun puzzles, wait for a sale as it discounts heavily.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Presentation (artwork, interface, sound, music) are all great.
+Characters and creatures are completely endearing and often humorous.
+DLC soundtrack includes 3 albums with 26 tracks total and is much cheaper than bandcamp.
+Built-in hint and walkthrough system (I never used the latter, so I can't comment on it).

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Puzzles are mostly intuitive trial and error, often requiring cleverness. No note taking needed.
~Puzzle difficulty is medium to devious in a few cases. Fans of The Room will be challenged. Fans of Myst will be fine.
~Two of the minigames/puzzles are more of action games. They're not difficult by any means, but are slightly out of place and run a bit too long.
~Your character's ability to adjust his height is under-utilized and inconsistent, leading to a few spots where you don't know what you can and can't interact with.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-Short game, and sets up for a sequel which never came about.
-The nuts and bolts "puzzle" can suck a fart out of my @$$. Unless you're skilled at complex tic-tac-toe and don't mind a merciless opponent, you'll want to Google "javascripter five in a row". Note that Lamkin's gambit no longer works.

Honestly, I cannot praise a game that gave me that of a hard time. Many, many times I dropped my mouse and left the game because of one puzzle I didn’t accomplish, or because I couldn’t find the key clue. I admit I used a guide to solve some of the most annoying puzzles, but still: the game managed to find a way to challenge me with brain requiring tasks or with retro arcade games that I have NO experience with from childhood. The implication is that as beautiful as the game might look with its mechanic, color reduced art style and its melancholic-epic soundtrack, it was no inspiring but rather a stressful experience I didn’t fully complete until today. Probably it is meant to be exactly like that: not every puzzle can be solved just by looking at, it takes several tries and a bit of brain effort, and maybe is speaks in Machinariums favor that I sticked to it as long as I did (over 5 hours in total). But when even the lead leaves me with a big question mark over my head, it saps my motivation to try again and again and again. 

I would only recommend it for the really persistent – and the well-prepared. So, in case you are up to a challenge and frustration-resistant, you can enjoy a in-depth designed game with a cute story and only few words needed.

83867989.review:
Puzzle games are like trying to defog a window: you might be able to see some of the translucent view in front of you, but you'll need to see which wipe best fixes the problem. "Machinarium" is like this, but not only are there a lot of wipes to choose from, you sometimes can't even see them in front of you.

"Machinarium" is a visual marvel, even years after its release. It's technological landscape allows both for a great variety of robots and neutral colors, and the few times where there is brightness really pop. Audio-wise, the game also is a success: the music and sound effects are ambient, quirky, and the "robo-talk" is delightful. The occasional humorous moments, like the neighbor upset at the robots playing music outside her window, or the robot upset that he lost Tic-Tac-Toe, are quite nice. There's a surprising amount of story and comedic material that the game gets out of its aesthetic and presentation style.

The gameplay itself is reminiscent of the point-and-click puzzle games of yesteryear, like "Myst." There are a series of objects, levers, and other such things that you can interact with. You gain an inventory as you progress through various rooms and puzzles, and you can also combine items in your inventory to increase their utility. I do appreciate when games do something interesting with the items you keep on you in order to vary up how to progress.

But alas, there were rather a few times playing the game where I wanted to throw up my hands and just say, "Okay...now what?" Assuming you've already clicked most things in the room to see what you can and cannot do, the game does provide a hint system for figuring out tasks, but even then, there's a problem: unlike "The Room" and "The Room Two," "Machinarium" only provides one VISUAL hint per puzzle, meaning that if you can't decipher what it is that you need to do, or it's something that you've already completed, you don't necessarily get that much of a hint at all. There is a way to get more overt help if you're truly struggling by playing a minigame, but that seems more like the game's way of admitting that some solutions are too obscure.

Part of this obscurity is because you cannot do certain things unless you are standing next to objects that you can interact with. Want to give the robot some oil? Whoops! You have to click to walk next to the robot before you can go to the inventory and select the oil. Want to get the drawer full of slides? Whoops! You have to click to walk next to the desk rather and THEN click the drawer, rather than simply clicking on the drawer from across the room. While this seems like a tiny annoyance, it makes the game more needlessly-cumbersome than it has to be. Especially for some of the more in-depth object interactions, having to place the objects in the exact spot the game demands of you was unwelcome. I'm sorry that I didn't put the ball bearings on the small space where the game wanted me to in the arbitrary time limit. Now I have to waste another minute to set this all up again.

There are other things gameplay-wise that don't make much sense. While I like the idea of being able to extend and contract yourself, the game allows you to walk while extended. Not only is there no reason whatsoever to do this (as no puzzles require it), but your walking speed is greatly reduced, making me wonder why it was programmed as an option in the first place. Combine this with not being able to easily cancel a walk cycle, and you can feel the seconds of your life getting wasted. The "Space Invaders" clone game was another unneeded touch, especially since it was part of a puzzle you had to complete. There are also an odd number of "middle steps" you need to take in order to solve some of these puzzles. Congratulations; you found a key! Oh...the key didn't work on the lock? Well, you should have gone back to the elevator and used the key there to open the door to get the freeze spray and then spray it on the lock which you can then smash...why not just have the key?

A good puzzle game makes the player feel rewarded for solving its brain-busters, but "Machinarium" left me scratching my head more than I'd like to admit and unfulfilled as I progressed and eventually beat it. I know this game has its enthusiasts, but I sadly am not one of them. The game is not terrible, not by any means! But as an experience, it left my empty. If you are compelled to give this game a try for yourself, wait for it to be on sale rather than the full asking price.

83591496.review:
Machinarium is perhaps the loveliest game I haven’t got a hope in hell of spelling or pronouncing correctly.

A sort of point’n’click/minipuzzle laden adventure which follows the story of a robot dumped in pieces on the outskirts of town returning to seek vengeance on those who dared cross him. 

Pros: 
The game is beautiful, the art style is seemingly timeless and I was shocked to see how old the game was.
The game is incredibly simple to pick up and play, and is relatively intuitive.
The game conveys information very well even without using much written information at all. 

Cons:
The game swings wildly between overly simple (the point and click aspects) and thigh tense-ingly frustrating (some of the minigames).
The game has no auto-save function, so when I crashed ¾ of the way in I was not happy. (Luckily you can skip to certain levels so the impact of this is minimal.)
The game is super short, with more than half my play time spent afk while I ate. 

Suggested improvements:
I’m tone deaf, the musical puzzle was a pain and I ended up googling for a solution, I didn’t think to use the in game hint page thing as I knew what I was meant to do. 
Having the notes and keys labelled from the offset would have been a big help.
An auto save function.

Overall recommendation:
If you enjoy point and click adventures then this is well worth a look. I’m hesitant to add a skill level to it due to the swings, but I think it would make a nice adventure to play alongside a child…  They’d 100% need help with the tougher minigames though.

You will understand the story perfectly from it, no worries. Hand-drawn graphic is very cute and suits the story nicely, one have to admire all the little details you can see on the screen. Soundtrack is also very good and catchy.
Wicked and devious robots from the Black Cap Brotherhood are terrorizing the city and its citizens. They have also kidnapped your girlfriend Berta and she is now their maid! To save her you have to find your way back into the city and help every unfortunate robot that crossed its way with the Brotherhood infamous members. And there are quite a lot of them!

Machinarium is filled with logical puzzles and mini games, some of them are easy some of them requires a little bit of out of the box thinking, but none should give you serious trouble. Everything you do have some meaning and all you need is usually very close to you.

83468539.review:
[b]Machinarium is a must play for fans of puzzle/adventure/point-and-click games[/b]

[u]Reasons to play:[/u]
[list]
[*]Beautiful artstyle
[*]Clever puzzles
[*]Inspired world
[*]Heartwarming story and characters
[*]Innovative hint system
[/list]
[u]Negatives:[/u]
[list]
[*]Very short
[*]Not optimal controls and mechanics
[*]Difficult? (this might be a negative)
[/list]


[hr][/hr]

 [h1] Review [/h1] 

At this point in time, Machinarium should be revered as a modern classic in the adventure game genre. It stands the test of time as an indie wonder which not only sparked an interest for the minimalist story-telling but brought back puzzle adventure games from the brink of Lucas Arts deathbed. As of writing this review I have replayed the game after not touching it for about 10 years, this time using an iPad. It is not truly an iPad review, neither can I accurately talk about the PC port more than the fact that they are very similar and I can happily recommend both.

I did refer to Lucas Arts, but truly Machinarium does not fully operate in the same space. Instead of dialogue driven adventures, Machinarium is more heavily reliant on puzzles. The inventory and item spamming on any interactive object or character is still there, but so are a good bunch of logic puzzles that take center-stage. This keeps a nice balance of the creative item interactions and the more logic driven brain teasers, without being too farfetched nor high IQ for the everyday player. Interactions with other characters are communicated with what I could describe as "supply and demand" thought bubbles that tells you how to progress or how to help out your fellow robot friend, while solutions are often narrowed down to a small amount of options. Even though you several times after finally finding a solution, smack your head because you should have found that solution earlier than you did. It is fun, satisfying and clever. Sometimes too clever for you, which brings me to a nice point. The hints.

Growing up with the likes of Lucas Arts games, in the time of no walkthroughs available, I think I developed thick skin to the most grueling and downright idiotic puzzles. Therefore I would never be the one to complain when a puzzle gets me really stuck, as I've seen many players do nowadays. Nevertheless the very player friendly hint system at play in Machinarium should be cherished. It consists of a hint button which gives 1 obscure hint (and 1 only) in the screen you're visiting, and a walkthrough book which are unlocked for the specific screen by playing a small minigame. The game thus challenges your patience by a minigame for you to be able to advance, which I think is a cute solution to the hint debacle which plagues present players. Did it have to exist? No. Am I happy it does? Certainly.

What about the game in general? The art is delivered in a warm palette, steampunk charm and rusty robotics. It is a city for the machines, where oil drinking, jazz bands, arcades and robot deities and coppers are prevalent. It is a city of ill-doers and bullies, old and young, lonely and lovely, cats and bugs. Spite it's cold robot heart, it is packed with character and adventure feel. Your protagonist can make himself bigger and smaller like an accordion which is easily accessible and if you idle for too long you will receive a flashback to happier times with your robot love. The sound design is delightful, while the story is just about right. The game could have been expanded upon and been given a more resonating ending, but as it stands, Machinarium is a great effort.

Some nitpicks though. If you want to interact with an object you have to move your character first to the spot to reach, which means traversing the world sometime isn't as smooth. Movement can also not be cancelled, so you might be making a wrong step and do a bunch of back and forth in this game, as movement animations can't be sped up either. But all in all these are minor complaints about time saving, which you won't need as the game is at max 4 hours long anyways.

A must play for adventure/puzzle game enthusiasts, a fringe game for those not familiar and a calming game for those that enjoy art and thought exercises. If not for the PC longplays, buy it for the tablet and just enjoy a soothing evening in the sofa.


[b]8/10[/b]

83075859.review:
[h1]As someone who doesn't play point & click games, this was a painful experience[/h1]

[quote]Before you start saying something along the lines of "if you don't play point & click games, why did you try this game in the first place", I have to admit that you are somewhat correct, however [b][i][u]I wanted to give the genre a try with this game, since a lot of people recommend me to try it[/u][/i][/b]. [/quote]

Let's start with the good things first, you can clearly tell there was a lot of effort put into this game, from the [b][i][u]captivating art style to the sound design and music[/u][/i][/b]. The game itself breeds a lot of life and makes me want to visit that place and meet all those people. To put it simply, [b][i][u]this game is eye candy[/u][/i][/b], but the moment you start playing the game you will realize how [b][i][u]bland and dull[/u][/i][/b] it really is.

[h1]Now, why did I not enjoy this game?[/h1]
To move and interact with the world you need to (as the name suggests) click on stuff, which leads to some very frustrating scenarios that pulled me out of the game:
First of all, [b][i][u]there is no clear distinction between what is interactable and what isn't[/u][/i][/b], where you can walk to and where you can't. You need to be physically close to that place for your cursor to tell you, and even then, [b][i][u]you need to have the pointer on top of it[/u][/i][/b]. I spent a significant amount of time just aimlessly moving my mouse to see if I bumped into something I could interact with.

That leads us to the second issue, which is [b][i][u]the puzzles[/u][/i][/b]. You will essentially encounter [b][i][u]two types of puzzles[/u][/i][/b] in this game. 
[list]
[*] The first, and most common one is to find something that unlocks what blocks your path. All the "depth" these puzzles could have is thrown out the window the moment you realize [b][i][u]you can just spam click on every single asset in the game[/u][/i][/b]. Sure, on paper the way you solve the puzzle sounds interesting, but gameplay wise [b][i][u]you are just backtracking around the map looking for trash just to unlock your path[/u][/i][/b]. And the solutions for these puzzles range from quite intuitive to pushing the boundaries of what’s logical.
[*] The second type of puzzles were the ones that would be considered challenging, it can be a hit or miss. [b][i][u]Some are pretty good; others are just a chore[/u][/i][/b] where I feel like I am constantly bumping into a wall until I find the solution.
[/list]
But by far, [b][i][u]the most annoying thing[/u][/i][/b] in this game is the [b][i][u]lack of responsiveness[/u][/i][/b]. [b][i][u]Every animation CAN’T be interrupted[/u][/i][/b], so if you do something you didn't wanted to do, you will be forced to watch the ENTIRE animation until your character is finished. 

Let's say you want to walk close to a door, but instead click the ladders that are right next to it, well TOUGH LUCK F*CKER, now you have to watch how he walks the ENTIRE WAY, goes up the ladders, and AFTER ALL THAT still be out of control watching the character go down the ladders. Sure, [b][i][u]it doesn't happen that often, and at best you will lose 15 seconds, but trust me, it’s frustrating and piles up fast[/u][/i][/b].

The game took me around [b][i][u]4 hours to finish[/u][/i][/b], but realistically speaking, it will take you between 3 and 6 depending on your playthrough. And I mean, that's fine, there are plenty of excellent games that are short, but [b][i][u]this game has no reason whatsoever to be replayed[/u][/i][/b]. 

[b][i][u]Once you finish this game, every subsequent game plays the same[/u][/i][/b], I could only see myself playing this game again for the art style. But if that's the case, what's the point of buying this game in the first place? You could easily appreciate the puzzles and the art style a lot more by just watching a YouTube playthrough.

TL;DR
If you don't like point and click games but are interested in this game because of the art style, [b][i][u]watch a walkthrough video instead[/u][/i][/b].

82946354.review:
A whimsical puzzle / adventure set in an imaginative dystopian robot world that is meticulously drawn and animated, in a style that fits both the world and the genre: rusty, nostalgic, a post-apocalyptic hybrid of steampunk and wall-e . All the elements come together perfectly, one of the high points is the music and the sound design. The puzzles are fair, the minigames, always part of the story and not put in randomly, make for a good change of pace. 

I applaud the creators' attempts at changing or refining established features of the genre when it comes to the controls and handling, with two exceptions: restricting your ability to do stuff to where you stand is a bad idea, especially as you're never quite sure whether something can't be done in general or isn't even attempted for lack of reach. You get used to that, however - unlike the other small problem the game suffers from, a brilliant idea actually, with a terrible execution. Each level offers an inbuilt walkthrough, a scribbled storyboard that helps you along if you're stuck - or don't know what you have to do in general. To unlock that storyboard, you have to play an arcade minigame, and that one is a spidery abomination with long stretches of empty space in between randomly generated repetitive stages.

Apart from that minor niggle (mentioned only because it is just so incomprehensibly bad in comparison to everything else), this game is a joy, and especially recommended for those adventure fans who need a change of pace from the verbosity and purple prose of others...

81766348.review:
I have been revisiting my love of point and clicks to spend more time having carefree gaming experiences. Besides revisiting my fav LucasArts and Sierra titles I decided to grab a few from Amanita Design and a few other studios to try out some well reviewed modern/newer titles.

Across the board the art for all their games is great. I've always had a great appreciation for art and media that makes the most of the limitations of the tools it is created with, and Amanita have deftly coaxed an aesthetic from Flash that reminds me of equal parts Terry Gillium animation and the René Laloux film Fantastic Planet. 

To be critical I did find that many of the puzzles were either easy with telegraphed solutions or mini-game styled brain teasers (which I find to be more like filler than more satisfying narrative/environment related puzzles).

And last but not least... 10/10 Sound Design and Composition. Wow. 100% inspired and always implemented in thoughtful ways that enhances the experience.

80469797.review:
While a gorgeous game with an exceptional soundtrack and adorable robots, the game is a mess from a technical and gameplay standpoint.

Glitchy when windowed, stuttery when fullscreen, especially if you try to stream it to someone, steam overlay doesn't work half the time, and when it does, it has a 2-3 second delay before  you can type anything. When windowed the cursor sometimes triggers the game to think it's out of focus, and it locks up, displaying intro logo. You have to click it to resume afterwards. Volume also resets to maximum constantly, no matter what you set it to.

From a gameplay perspective it's not doing that great either.

This is more of a subjective thing, but puzzles go from very interesting and clever environmental puzzles to generic "flash games puzzles" style content with lighting up random thingies, matching patterns or even a particularly annoying one which is a twist on tic-tac-toe breaking the flow of the story.

Other times things that are obvious you should be able to do using your adjustable height/extending hands (judging from previous interactions) simply don't work, the game forcing you to do it in a particular way instead. There are also some puzzles that are borderline moon logic. The one where you boil a f***ing metal radiator and turn it into a RUBBER hose was extremely dumb and i got it right by accident. 

There are also confusing interaction situations where you're not sure why stuff doesn't work (mostly because you aren't in the right place) or how to get your little guy to go where you want him to. 

While odd to point as a negative, there is also the fact that you are offered a bit too much freedom at times, and you may end up not knowing what exactly are you missing from the chain of give-that-for-this and leaving you confused. The transitions between certain screens are also painfully slow which only accentuates the frustration of going back and forth.

This game is a great point and click with beautiful artworks and a cute story.
As always with that kind of game, I gave myself the challenge of not using any hints during the whole thing and it wasn't too hard since the puzzles are very intuitive and it's pretty easy to pick up the logic behind. 

Clickable items are usually slightly different than the rest of the graphics so it's fairly easy to spot them. The zoom feature was also useful into that matter from time to time.

There is no written or audible dialogue, the storyline is shown to us through simple animations.

I like that when you progress in the game the character disposes of items that are no longer useful and refuses to go back to locations where we have finished all of our business, it avoid unecessary exploring of places where we are already done. 

I saw in the controls menu that with a game controller you could press "B" to cancel an action. The equivalent on the keyboard doesn't seems to exist. At least it wasn't mentioned in their menu and I didn't figured out other way of doing that. It's the only thing that I've found to be slightly irritating sometimes, because if you missclick you then have to wait until the character ends its animation to resume playing. As far as I'm concerned this was the only tiny flaw that I have noticed into that game. But nothing to worry about really.

77977983.review:
Machinarium has delivered one of the most memorable game experiences that will stay with you for years to come. This is a game that would be in my all time favourite indie game list if I had one and here’s why:

Using  this type of [u][b]artwork[/b][/u] for a video game was a really good idea. The game’s not new anymore, yet it looks like it could have been made in 2020. It’s artistic in a way that makes it ageless. Every scene looks like a painting - if nothing else, it’s just beautiful to look at. Furthermore, bringing in the theme of a machine city, gives it a very Gigerish feel, if you happen to be familiar with the mastermind behind the Alien movie designs. But where Giger mixed horror with eroticism, Machinarium comes off cute and weird – like steampunk. Machinarium is like steampunk mixed with Giger’s artwork.

Machinarium is first and foremost a [u][b]puzzle game[/b][/u]. The puzzles are strong and tied to logic. I did feel frustrated at times when I was unable to see the solutions, but I always ended up admitting to myself that I had overlooked something of importance and it was not the game designer’s bad choices. The puzzles also help with enhancing the experience in how they’ve been executed. They’re conducted in a makeshift fashion that you would expect from a world that looks like a huge junkyard and solving them feels fun.

[u][b]Sounds[/b][/u] in Machinarium do not carry any articulated messages so any meaningful information is delivered through visual and auditory imagery. They did stumble here a bit with the most obvious case being the usage of the word „Oil”, which did stand out as a failure where it was occurred. I wish they had stayed true to the main principle without any exception. It’s usually tricky to pull off, but if used correctly then the effect is very strong and really helps with putting one’s fantasy to work.

Besides puzzles, game obstacles also came in the form of [u][b]mini-games[/b][/u] and here Machinarium pays homage to many classic games including arcade games. Boy did I have fun with the mini games of Machinarium! The only letdown was the one you had to play if you wanted hints to help you with the puzzles. I wish they had made it more dynamic and interesting. Currently it just feels like chores you have to endure if you wish to see some hints.

To [u][b]sum things up[/b][/u], I wish to bring out the most important: the game feels and looks iconic. Overall it was a very well executed, emotionally satisfying and challenging experience which will get my highest recommendations.

77691177.review:
I bought this game from the creator's website years ago and loved it so much I bought it for a friend who didn't have a dime of entertainment money so that hopefully he would enjoy as much as I did. I purchased it again on Steam so that I could have it in my library to not only play again, but also have it for my daughter when she gets a little older.

The soundtrack is probably my most favorite game soundtrack of all time. It is worth purchasing even if you have never played the game and it makes for great chill or meditative music, especially when you are in an industrious or contemplative state-of-mind. The visuals are artistically stunning and the puzzles can be challenging while not being overly frustrating. For the most part, the puzzles can be figured out pretty linearly but the hint system is cool as it give you the right direction to head towards when you feel like you've been wandering around too long.

The best advice I can give is:  Press the Space Bar when fighting spiders.

Overall, Machinarium is a very soothing and relaxing experience. The story is cute, and does an amazing job at not needing a single word to tell it. It is definitely one of the top point-and-click games of all time, joining (or maybe surpassing) many of the classic LucasArts and King's Quest games.

77470677.review:
As a person who is not a huge fan of point-and-click adventure games, Machinarium, has done a great job at creating an approachable game for those not big into that genre. It has an environment that reminds me a mix between The Stinky Cheese Boy (children's book), Little Big Planet, and the Oddworld series. It's darker, yet charming, and it offers a strong hint system that is gated behind fun arcade-like games.

Overall, the graphics work well, the controls are easy to use, and it has a fun storyline that I think would work well with others joining you on the adventure.

For a full review, check out: https://www.neverendingbacklog.com/episodes/never-ending-backlog-machinarium

[b]Although Machinarium is a relative new game (released on 2009), it is already considered a classic one among point and click adventure gamers. Machinarium is a masterpiece indeed.


Manometer: 9/10[/b]


The good
- Fantastic hand-drawn graphics.
- Well designed world with tons of little details.
- Characters are adorable. Especially Josef.
- Nice animations. Josef reactions are hilarious.
- It packs some of the best puzzles you can find out there. At the right difficulty level too.
- Clever idea to include these vintage mini games. 
- Lovely simplistic "robotic" music.
- Good sound design. Some robotic sounds are really funny.
- This bulling story is sad and funny simultaneously.
- The hint and guide systems (if you need it) are unique.
- It' s obvious everywhere in the game that the developers has put a lot of passion on it.

The bad
- If you miss-click somewhere and Josef starts walking you cannot cancel this move by quickly clicking somewhere else. You must wait for Josef to finish his move.
- Could be longer.

75953495.review:
Major Update:  I have found the fix for controller support finally!!!   
You must run the Compatibility Troubleshooter for the main game file .exe
1. Go to main game file .exe
2. Right click, go to Properties
3. Go to Compatibility Tab
4. Run the Compatibility Troubleshooter
5. Follow the prompt (have your controller ON) Test the Game button.
5. It will launch the game ... Tah Dah ... it works.
6. Exit the game, go to NEXT, Apply These Settings (it will run the game in Win 8)

My sincerest apologies to the Developers,  I will pass this info on to them (they didn't know)

75211928.review:
A really fun and intuitive puzzle adventure point & click game - Machinarium is yet another fantastic piece of art from the developer ''Amanita Design''.

The game starts in a futuristic world of robots, as your character is dumped into a scrapyard, where your journey to freedom and happiness begins.

The game has no dialog and the story of your past and what had led you to your misfortune is told through short animated bits of memories.

You can interact with items and the environment only if they are in close proximity and your character's ability to stretch its body adds up to the fun. 

The game offers you a hint option in the form of retro-style mini-games.

As I mentioned the game is a really fun piece of art but is relatively short, thus feel free to buy when on discount, but nonetheless, you won't regret adding Machinarium as part of your great puzzle collection and enjoy it with friends and family.

This is mid-recommendation. The game is an artistic and visual achievement but also a horrible annoying one. The game has no qualms about wasting your time, yet some puzzle hit the perfect difficulty spot. Minigames are completely worthless, generic and all around time wasters. I've had this game on other platforms since it came out, but I have just finished it. The game has received QOL updates since the version I remember, but still has no autosave. The game is exactly how to do a game with top notch visual story telling, animation, visual and world cohesiveness AND how NOT to treat the players time. Lastly the connect 5 is way to hard. Feels like the opponent is programmed to always draw, with occasional matches in which the opponent does only 1 mistake, in which if it not taken advantage of, the game results in a stalemate once again. Am not ashamed to say I cheated for this. Way to hardcore for a simple point & click game.

Like I've said before, the games high points are exceptional, but the low points are so frustrating and annoying that the game leaved me with very bitter impression.

73716316.review:
Machinarium is an okay and cute Point and Click, Puzzle game. So the story.

Josef a little robot from the great city Machinarium has found himself in the scrap yard separated from his friend, but just because he's far from home doesn't mean he's going to sit by and do nothing, he will get home to his friend one way or the other.

Okay now the likes. The art style is really good and cute, it has this picture book kind of feel to it witch I like it’s again pretty cute, and the levels in the game were fun to explore or just stop and look at.

The story was good, like with the game Dropsy, there is no dialogue spoken it's all just picture balloons which is nice, the game does well to convey its story through that. 

The mini game you can play to unlock the walkthrough was pretty cool and kind of fun. The games puzzle are a mixed bag for me some could be good some could just be a real pain.

Okay now the dislikes. As I said the puzzles are a mixed bag some are good, but others can be a real pain to figure out.  

Then there is the mini game you play to unlock the walkthrough, the problem with that is that it doesn't stay unlocked in the level you're doing, your going to have to play the mini game to see the walkthrough for that level.

In the game you can’t give a person an item or get an item without being right next to it. You see an other Point and Click games when you see an item or you have an item for someone you click it/them and no matter how far away the main character is they walk right over to the item or person. But in this game it does not have that; you have to be right next to them to do that which can be a pain.

And lastly the game is a bit too expensive like it's  almost fifteen bucks it makes sense it was like $9 or 10 but almost 15, is definitely a bit too high.

So with that all said and done with Machinarium is an okay and cute Point and Click, Puzzle game, with a really good and cute art style, fun levels to explorer and a good story. So if your looking for a cute point-and-click puzzle game you may like this.

73406287.review:
Machinarium is one of the most beautiful point-and-click games I've ever come across. I wasn't too impressed with the puzzles at the beginning, but after you get the hang of the gameplay, it gets more and more fun to play. The characters are really charming and the world building is just absolutely remarkable. I'd love to see more of this world come to life, I really do appreciate the mechanism designs and everything.

There are a few puzzles that I did not like playing- it's like trying to solve a Rubik's cube in the middle of wanting to play a point-and-click game. I am looking to replay this just to appreciate the environment and experience better, but the prospect of having to deal with these puzzles all over again is making me hesitate. (I'd rather not use a guide for the puzzles themselves too.)

The music is gorgeous. It truly brings the artwork to another level, something I don't see to this extent in many pieces of media. Actually I don't even mind just staying in one spot just to listen to those robot musicians play their song. 

Also, Josef is a really cute character, I especially loved his tiny dances and adorable noises. I was actively rooting for him the entire way.

I think everyone who's a fan of point-and-click games should get this. Definitely not regretting any of it on my part. Might be one of my top favorite point-and-click games.

73241038.review:
Like many of the reviewers here, I played Machinarium several years ago and recently decided to buy it again on steam. 

The point and click genre has seen hundreds of amazing gems since the late 80's. What makes Machinarium stand out is its amazing puzzles and mini-games, the gorgeous art, and the music, which is one of the best works by Tomas Dvorak (aka Floex).
 
The only problem I had was that some paths might not be obvious since they're blended so well with the background. I missed a pipe on a screen at some point and was wandering around like crazy, not knowing where to go. Also, the puzzles test different aspects of intelligence (sound, spatial awareness, patterns, logic, reflexes, etc). Although the puzzles are manageable with some effort, some puzzles might seem harder than others. This isn't necessarily a bad thing though. I like how different some of the puzzles seem from each other and from the puzzles in other point and click games.   

Revisiting this gem was an awesome, feel-good experience. One of the best adventure games ever made.

73158424.review: Stunning game, so much fun and beautiful music too.

73157489.review:
What a fabulous game. It is so much above the ordinary! Machinarium is a mixture of pure puzzle (such as solving a moving marble puzzle to open a lock) and inventory-based adventure game (such as picking up a flower stem, which later you will plant in a pot in another building).

SPOILER ALERT : - If you really want to enjoy the game without having any degradation in fun levels and wanna leave it to to your intuitive thinking of solving puzzles, STOP READING and buy this game right away . THE REVIEW BASICALLY ENDS HERE.

You're in a wonderfully drawn and painted world inhabited by robots. There are no words spoken when robots interact. Rather you see thought balloons with a little video that moves the story along, or a pictogram or figure of an item that a robot wants. The way emotions are portrayed without words is inventive. Reminds me of the movie "Wall-E".

The protagonist is just as cute as Wall-E. He's a little robot who's sweet on a little girl robot. Unfortunately, there are bully robots, and their evil plans must be thwarted.

I thought all of the puzzles were pretty challenging and some of them are DIFFICULT. Wow - hurt my brain and I got tired of me muttering to myself, "No, that doesn't work. Maybe if I move it this way." Only one, to defuse a bomb, is timed, and if you don't make it in time, the game dumps you back to right before you started working on the bomb. I "died" the first time, but what was good (for me) is that what you managed to learn the first time still holds true the 2nd time, so the 2nd time I didn't need as much time and defused the bomb.

If you need a hint, there's a little lightbulb over the scene. When you click on it, it gives you a pictogram of what you need to do next. The lightbulb didn't help me much, because I generally knew what I was supposed to do, I just had trouble finding out how to do it. What was much more useful, however, was the booklet, "machinarium walkthrough" that came with this Collector's Edition. The walkthrough is a work of art, itself. The whole thing is in handdrawn pictures/pictograms, such as the thought balloons in the game. It is marvelous! And I had to resort to it more than once, though I'm not sure why I couldn't figure out on my own that bringing bees into the oil pub to distract the bartender was the way to get the barrel out the door.

There was only one "puzzle" that I really didn't like and that was the giant one at the end. It's like a pac-man game where you have lives and after you unlock a gun you have to "get" 33 red evil robots in order to finish the puzzle, including finding the buggers as you go from one screen to another trying to make your way through a maze. I don't like games like that and I'm not good at games like that (latter contributes to the former, of course!). Though I could tell that it was much slower, etc., than real pac-man, I still had trouble (reflexes of a slug) and just got annoyed that I had to do this to proceed. Brain-puzzles I love. Reflex puzzles I don't. BUT - I'm sure most people wouldn't have trouble with it, so there you go. And fortunately for me, the booklet that stays throughout the gameplay on the screen has a map of the maze, so at least I could figure out where I was.

Regards,
A Happy Gamer

73086325.review:
A charming game that places an indefatigable and likable android protagonist in an overall melancholy and wistful setting of crumbling edifices, broken machines, and seedy robots. (Naturally, as developer of Primordia, I find this a very congenial setup.) The game has no dialogue or text, and it aspires less to high philosophy than to episodic cartoon travails, but this works quite well and doesn't overstay its welcome. Beautiful artwork and excellent music round out the charm. 

The puzzles are more in the vein of a Flash game than a traditional point-and-click (frequently they are focused on a single room, and typically they involve minigame logic challenges rather than inventory-based problem solving), but they are fair and in some instances quite clever. I found the integrated hint system, which I used a couple of times, less than fully helpful.

All said, this is a favorite of critics and players alike for good reason -- it is a game with character and integrity, available for a song.

I was able to complete the game in 9 hours and that's without using the clue feature every time I got stuck. Overall, a great little game. No replayability is the only negative point.

72434983.review:
I first bought [i]Machinarium[/i] on GOG, it was my introduction to Amanita Design and remains my favourite of their works, I'd even argue it's objectively their best. Even though it's just a simple point-and-click adventure with the most basic story imaginable, the world is so visually unique and fascinating I think that lifts the whole game into something really special. The other part of this is of course the music, which is absolutely gorgeous (I would recommend getting the OST as well honestly.) I love the art style, the dingy industrial city full of ersatz robotic NPCs, crumbling interiors with surprising homely touches, and no real explanation as to how this world came to be. 

It's quite a short game but I like to fire it up every now and then just to experience the atmosphere (my playtime is longer than it appears since I did most of this on the GOG version,) so there's some replay value there.

This game is literally the most unbelievably frustrating experience. It's probably even more frustrating because it's a *gorgeous* game.

71790991.review:
Classic point 'n' click with a lot of charm. Firstly the pros; simple but interesting story set in a rather unique world. No puzzle too obtuse but still challenging enough to get your brain thinking. Best of all, no pixel hunting! Soundtrack is also very fitting for the game.

As for criticisms it would have been great if the game took you to more diverse/interesting areas as the colour palette/environment did start to get a bit repetitive after a while. As far as puzzles go I found the item-finding and combining/using elements not too challenging (if you grew up with games like Monkey Island then this will be a breeze!) but there were a couple of minigames that stumped me for quite some time, especially toward the end of the game. That said, I beat this without a guide in around 6 hours and didn't face any major frustrations. 

Overall if you're looking for a great little point 'n' click adventure then this will do the trick. Whilst it doesn't do anything particularly new it is a solid addition to a beloved genre and deserves all of the praise it has received.

70839943.review:
HYPE: 
I played the demo YEARS ago and was waiting to be able to play all of it for some time. I'd forget about it at times but it was always in the back of my head as a challenging but pretty, cute and engaging P&C game.

Well I finally got it on steam and.. I really don't like it as much...

FIRST IMPRESSIONS:
It's absolutely beautiful, just like I remembered! The music is nice and calming.
It's fluid enough in how it looks and sounds, and has maintained the general vibe/spirit of the demo, which is great!

So... why is this a negative review?

PUZZLES:
The puzzles are kinda irritating.
I like how you have a hint book, but the method you need to do to open it was... unique.
I don't like shooter games, so that wasn't a fun puzzle to do to open the book, but it's super easy, so there's that.
But then I realised if you leave a room/area, then the hint book is closed again for that room and you need to unlock it again.
Why?!
Shooting spiders is really not that fun...

I guess the positive is it's a change of pace from thinking hard about what the puzzle wants you to do.
And yes, it's about what the puzzle wants. Not what is logical.
I've seen other reviews touch on it and I was glad I wasn't alone in thinking WTF, where is the logic? Why is it so long winded?

It's really, really satisfying to finish a complex puzzle. But when it's all trial and error, I don't feel mentally rewarded.

Every time I finish a puzzle, I close the game down for a break. Because I don't feel enthusiastic about the next one I'm just kinda sitting there frowning like 'ok...'.


HINT BOOK:
You'd think the hint book would help for disgruntled and confused players like me, who clearly don't have the same brand of logic as the game, but the hint book is quite cyptic, often only telling you bits of information, but not clearly and not in the right order, or with missing steps.

This is great because it doesn't spoil stuff too much and it stops you feeling like you're 'cheating' if you use it. It's a puzzle trying to understand the hints.

But it's not super successful because at times... I managed to solve the puzzle and would go back to the hint book and still be confused as to how the hint's reflected what I had to do!!

OVERALL:
I think the game is great looking, the music is nice and calming and it has a wonderful atmosphere. 
However, it's suffering from padding. 
They make unexpected puzzle answers to force you into trial and error, so it takes you longer and in theory, feels like an achievement when you figured it all out.  Except it doesn't.
They have a wonderful hint book which is implemented in a smart way, but the hints are so cryptic that sometimes they don't even make sense after you've successfully completed the puzzle!

I probably would still recommend it to some people, if they have more patience and are ok with trial and error puzzles. Or if they just want to get lost in the beautifully drawn world.
But overall, I think the core part of the game, the actual gameplay, ended up being a little disappointing. :(

70612959.review: Machinarium is a charming point and click adventure adventure about a robot trying to save his girlfriend. The puzzles can be a bit tricky at times but are still fun (there's also a hint book you can unlock by playing a minigame if you get really stuck).

70508702.review: What a magical game! It's truly like stepping into a whole new world, with incredible art, excellent visual storytelling, and an immersive soundtrack (which I just bought on vinyl!). A lot of the puzzles (especially later on) gave me that "ah-A!" moment when I finally figured out what I needed to do, and despite its cute appearance, the mini-games are actually surprisingly tough, but in a good way! The only thing I would change would be to have a map - since I played this game over a long period, I kept forgetting how to get to specific places, so repeating some of the actions or walking around because I took the wrong stairs or something was a tiny bit tedious...but at the same time, this is clearly intended to be a single run-through sort of game so I can't fault it for that. I definitely recommend it!

69905755.review:
From the creators of Samorost and Samorost 2 brings you Machinarium, Machinarium like Samorost 1&2 is point and click, but only if the main character is within reach.  Machinarium brings in more types of puzzles, creative story. 

Art style is full of soul being hand drawn with pencil and pen to capture the steampunk robot atmosphere. Puzzles were from easy as 1 2 3 to keyboard crashing difficult. Luckily there is a cheat book that is opened through a mini game that can reveal how solve the puzzles. There is not a single word spoken, only through pictures in speech bubbles. Combined with the wordless storytelling, the unique artstyle and music, point and click genre,  and setting makes it fitting to not only consider Machinarium to be a masterpiece game but also an artistic masterpiece as well.

Buy during steam sale through Amanita Design Bundle to play more games made by same creator; Amanita Design. One of the most underrated games made by an underappreciated developer.

Machinarium is a neat point and click game. The characters are charming, the aesthetic is a perfect smash up of cute and gritty, and it's got a pretty sick soundtrack that suits the game perfectly. That being said, like a lot of point and click games, sometimes the solutions are so baffling that you end up randomly clicking around or consulting a walkthrough. I generally expect to need additional help with older indie point and click games anyway.
To sum up, if you like artistic, quirky indie point and click games and don't mind using a walkthrough, you'll appreciate this game. I definitely did.
